editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

OR, Sea≈øonable REFLECTIONS ON THE Novelties of Rome: WITH The Ri≈øe, Growth, and Final Overthrow of ANTICHRIST now at Hand: Occa≈øioned by the Preface to a Treati≈øe called N∆≤BES TESTI∆≤M, OR, A Collection of Primitive Fathers giving Te≈øtimony to the Faith once delivered to the Saints, Being (as the Author ≈øtileth it) A full Di≈øcovery of the Sentiments of the Ancient Fathers in the chief Points of Controver≈øy at pre≈øent under debate.

div.head: TO THE KING OF ENGLAND, And all Crowned Heads, and Soveraign Princes whatever.
div.p: IT is the Advice of the Royal Prophet to you his Royal Brethren, P≈øal. 2. 10, 11, 12. Be Wi≈øe now therefore O ye Kings, be instructed ye Judges of the Earth: Serve the Lord with Fear, and rejoice with Trembling: Ki≈øs the Son le≈øt he be angry, and ye peri≈øh from the way when his Wrath is kindled but a little, Ble≈ø≈øed are all they that put their tru≈øt in him. And the rea≈øon of it was, beeau≈øe he that ≈øitteth in the Heavens, who is ≈øo much Superiour to the highe≈øt of them all, had ≈øet his King upon his holy Hill of Zion, ver. 6. and as the re≈øult of his Eternal Decree, had bid him ask of him, and he would give him the Heathen for his Inheritance, and the uttermo≈øt parts of the Earth for his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, ver. 7, 8, and as the Effect of that his Royalty, he ≈øhould break them with a Rod of Iron, and da≈øh them in pieces like a Potters Ve≈ø≈øel.

Now the time ≈øeems to draw on, when this is to befully accompli≈øh'd; and is it not the duty of the Watchman to
give the warning before it is too late? For what will it advantage to be told of Danger, when it will not be in your Power to prevent it? To be minded of the Approach of Chri≈øt's Kingdom, when his Iron Rod ≈øhall be ≈øhaking over you, and your Power, your Intere≈øts, your Alliances, your Glory, your Wealth, and Kingdoms all da≈øhing in pieces again≈øt one another? For if you chance to be of tho≈øe, who give your Power to the Bea≈øt, this will unavoidably be your Fate, both yours and Babylon's in one Hour to come to Confu≈øion, Rev. 18. 10.

For the preventing whereof, this following Treati≈øe is here with all humility pre≈øented; and may it among tho≈øe many Voices and Trumpets which have of late ≈øounded to the World, have that good effect to awaken your mo≈øt Serene Maje≈øties, to what alone is your true intere≈øt of State, and that is, to hate the Whore, and make her de≈øolate and naked, Rev. 17. 16. for otherwi≈øe there can be nothing better expected, than to partake of her Plagues, Rev. 18. 4.

Would you (Soveraign Princes) as it befel Nebuchadnezzar, your Golden Head, as he is called, Dan. 2. 38. be contented, it ≈øhould be be ≈øaid to you, the Kingdom is departed from you, and they ≈øhall drive you from among≈øt Men? Dan. 4. 31, 32.

Would you be contented to ≈øee the Hand put forth before you, and MENE MENE, TEKEL written on the Walls of all your Palaces, as it was to Bel≈øhazzar, when he lifted up him≈øelf again≈øt the Lord of Heaven, Dan. 5. 23? &c. If not, then vouch≈øafe to take the Warning, and ≈øubmit in time to that Kingdom, which, it is ≈øaid, the God of Heaven ≈øhould ≈øet up in their Days, and in the days of tho≈øe other Monarchies which were to ≈øucceed in the World, Dan. 2. 44. For it was not for nothing, that ≈øo much Scorn and Contempt was
thrown upon tho≈øe mighty Monarchs; Monarchs, who were ≈øo indeed; for they wanted no Allies, or Confederates to ≈øupport them; for they were Kings of Kings, Dan. 2. 37. and all People, Nations, and Languages trembled and feared before them, whom they would they ≈ølew, and whom they would they kept alive; and whom they would they ≈øet up, and whom they would they put down, Dan. 5. 19. Believe it (great Sirs) it was not for nothing that ≈øuch memorable Examples were ≈øet forth, it was for your Admonition, upon whom the Ends of the World are come; as it is 1 Cor. 10, 11. 'Twas that after Ages might grow Wife, as knowing there is no re≈øi≈øting that Soveraign, who is higher than the highe≈øt; no withstanding that Power which can ≈øo ea≈øily break in pieces, and con≈øume all other Kingdoms, but it ≈øelf ≈øhall ≈øtand for Ever, Dan. 2. 44.

It hath in Effect done all this already, the Babylonian, the Per≈øian, the Greek Monarchies have already been utterly de≈øtroyed by it, and the Roman ≈øo far, as to ≈øtand upon its la≈øt Legs, (or rather to expre≈øs it in the words of the Vi≈øion, Dan. 2. 33.) to have both its Legs and Feet ≈øo broken, as to ≈øtand only on ≈øome of its Toes; Some of tho≈øe ten Kings I mean, which after the taking of Rome, became the parts and ≈øupport of that Empire.

And as Daniel ≈øaid to Nebuchadnezzar, Thou art this Head of Gold, Dan. 2. 38. So to you, O Kings, may it be ≈øaid, you are tho≈øe Toes; it is on you ≈øub≈øi≈øts, what is ≈øtill behind, of the la≈øt Monarchy, as it hath been divided into ≈øeveral Kingdoms; and of how great concern mu≈øt it be to you to be rightly informed how you may perpetuate your Royalty, and ≈øo e≈øtabli≈øh your Thrones, that you may not be of tho≈øe, whom the Stone cut out without Hands, ≈øhall ≈ømite and break in pieces, Dan. 2. 34?

Think let Men, what they will, of the outward Weakne≈øs of Chri≈øts Kingdom, of the little A≈ø≈øi≈øtance it hath, or is like to meet with in the World; let there be no Hand ≈øeen to cut out this Stone, no humane Strength or Policy, that is ready to contribute toward the forming of it, yet it will grow into a great Mountain, and fill the whole Earth, ver. 34, 35. The Gold, the Silver, the Bra≈øs, the Iron, and Cley mu≈øt all give place to it; it is a goodly Image indeed, which the≈øe make in Nebuchadnezzar's Vi≈øion, but it is but an Image, and mu≈øt vani≈øh before this Stone, as the Dream, that fir≈øt prefented it.

Be Wife now therefore, let me again repeat it, O ye Kings; be in≈øtructed ye Judges of the Earth; let nothing draw you from what is your true Intere≈øt, let none of the Allurements, none of the Sorceries of the great Whore, of her, who hath glorified her ≈øelf, and lived deliciou≈øly, who hath ≈øaid in her Heart, I ≈øit a Queen, and am no Widdow, and ≈øhall ≈øee no Sorrow, but who≈øe Plagues notwith≈øtanding ≈øhall come in one Day; let no tenderne≈øs for her, with whom any of you have lived deliciou≈øly make you pity, bewail, and lament her, le≈øt your Judgment too come in one Hour with hers, Rev. 18. 7, 8, 9, 10. No; ≈øtand as far off as you can, for fear of her Torment; ha≈øten away, ha≈øten away, that the Ruins of her Fall reach you not.

You ≈øee how certainly all is foretold, you ≈øee how much of this is already begun; what is behind, for your Kingdoms, (and what ≈øhould be more dear to you than your mo≈øt glittering Crowns,) for you Souls ≈øake dread, and avoid.

But who can hope to be ≈øo happy as to be heard on this Subject, when what is here written, like the Religion ≈øhe teaches, mu≈øt be to many of you in an unknown Language, and were it worthy to ≈øpeak in your ≈øeveral
Tongues, would be ≈øure to find all the Tricks and little Policies of corrupt Courtiers imployed in keeping it from your Knowledge: Every thing that is imaginable, to be≈øpeak your di≈ølike both of Work and Author to be in≈øinuated into your Royal Ears.
Is any thing that is new, offered; what a proper Topick is here to traduce the Man, as one who is Forward, Pragmatical, and Self-conceited?
Is it deep and My≈øterious? How much better were it to let alone ≈øuch unprofitable Speculations, and not be overbu≈øie in what our wi≈øer Forefathers were content to be Mode≈øt and Ignorant.

Is it ≈øerious, and doth he who pre≈øumes to Adre≈øs you, be≈øpeak your Royal Audience with the Sen≈øe of his greater Authority, from whom he brings the Me≈ø≈øage, is not this to make too bold with ones Superiours, and exceed the limits of that Humility which becomes a dutiful Subject?
Is the Stile in which he writes, grave, and plain; then ≈øhall all pre≈øently be dull and in≈øipid, not fit for a refined Courtier, much le≈øs for a Prince to lo≈øe his time in.

Is it on the contrary, what the mo≈øt accurate Criticks cannot ≈øo ea≈øily carp at? Is the Author in his Education and Studies one who hath had as great Advantages as others, and hath endeavoured to imploy histime to as good purpo≈øe as the highe≈øt of their fine Wits? Then much Learning ≈øhall have made Paul mad: He is a little Cracked, or Enthu≈øia≈øtical, or any thing el≈øe that may bla≈øt an hone≈øt Man.

Or if his Fame be too clear to be directly ≈øtruck at; yet may he not be pitied to Death? and out of pretence of high Compa≈ø≈øion to a Man of ≈øuch abilities, may it not be repre≈øented as a great ∆≤nhappine≈øs, that he ≈øhould have made ≈øo ill a choice of his Subject to
treat on? That in any thing el≈øe he would have done better, and how great a Misfortune it is, that his Talent was not otherwi≈øe imployed?

Or if nothing el≈øe will murther his Reputation, and neither he, nor the Work be otherwi≈øe liable to Exceptions, yet ≈øhall it not be whi≈øpered, that he is none of Cae≈øar's Friends? That your Crowns and Royal Dignities them≈øelves are not ≈øafe, if it ≈øhall be allowed to every Pen to vent ≈øuch Anti-monarchical Doctrines, as have been brought into the World under the pretence of carrying on the Kingdom of Chri≈øt, and advancing its Power and Triumphs: Was not that the very Rea≈øon St. Chry≈øo≈øtom gives, as is particularly ob≈øerved p. 16. of this following Treati≈øe, why St. Paul ≈øpeaks ≈øo Enigmatically, and Ob≈øourely of this Matter in his Epi≈øtle to the The≈ø≈øalonians, ch. 2 2. v. 5, 6, &c. Why then ≈øhould any be ≈øo Pre≈øumptuous to meddle with ≈øuch great My≈øteries?
∆≤nhappy Princes to be thus Treated! and yet what Court almo≈øt is there, or hath ever been, where ≈øuch ba≈øe Whi≈øperers and Para≈øites have not made up great part of the Attendants?

∆≤nhappy Princes too! who mu≈øt neither ≈øee with your own Eyes, nor hear with your own Ears, but are ≈øubject even in what is of highe≈øt moment to be mi≈øled by the ≈ølanders of tho≈øe, who≈øe greate≈øt Merit it is, to depre≈øs ≈øuch, who≈øe Sincerity and Plain-dealing aims at nothing ≈øo much, as to e≈øtabli≈øh you upon tho≈øe Foundations, which only can ≈øtand.

And were you at lei≈øure to read all your re≈øpective Hi≈øtories; who in all Ages would be found to be the true≈øt Friends to Monarchy? tho≈øe, who flattered your Predece≈ø≈øors into Ruin, or tho≈øe who were ≈øo hardy, as at their greate≈øt Peril to endeavour to recover them from it?

Or if your great Affairs will not permit ≈øuch a particular re≈øearch, let me have leave to give it you in an In≈øtance out of that Hi≈øtory, which you are all concerned to be acquainted with, it is that we have upon Sacred Record, and in the Truth and Moral of it, is beyond all Exception; you have the relation of it, Kings 1. 22. Ahab King of I≈ørael, and Jeho≈øhaphat King of Judah, were going out to Battle again≈øt the Syrians, and Jeho≈øhaphat ≈øaid unto the King of I≈ørael, Enquire I pray thee at the Word of the Lord to Day: Upon this the Prophets are gathered together, about four hundred Men, (a full Convocation) the que≈øtion is put, ≈øhall I go again≈øt Ramoth Gilead to Battel, or ≈øhall I forbear? and they ≈øaid, Go up, for the Lord ≈øhall deliver it into the hand of the King; only Micaiah hath no Summons ≈øent him, he had in all likelihood been traduced as one who favoured not the Royal Cau≈øe; I hate him ≈øaith Ahab, for he doth not Prophe≈øy good concerning me, but evil: However at the In≈øtance of Jeho≈øhaphat he is ≈øent for, and what is the I≈ø≈øue? at fir≈øt he bids him too (the Me≈ø≈øenger ≈øent for him had prepared him for it) Go, and Pro≈øper; but upon the King's adjuring that he tell nothing but what is true in the Name of the Lord; he then plainly and hone≈øtly acquaints him with the danger, is huffed for it by the Court Prophets, impri≈øoned by the King, and left there to expect the farther effects of his Di≈øplea≈øure, when he ≈øhould return in Peace; he never returns in Peace, but is ≈ølain, to fulfil the Words of the hone≈øt Prophet, he had di≈øgraced.

Now who were here the mo≈øt Loyal? Tho≈øe Prophets who ≈øaid to Ahab, go up to Ramoth-Gilead and pro≈øper, the words of whom declared good to the King with one Mouth, and thereby betrayed him to the ≈øad Fate, which ≈øo ≈øoon overtook him, 1 Kings 22. 12, 13. Or Micaiah,
who ≈øhewed him I≈ørael ≈øcattered upon the Hills, as Sheep that had no Shepherd, v. 17. Who ≈øhewed him the Lord ≈øitting on his Throne, and all the Ho≈øt of Heaven ≈øtanding by him on his Righthand, and on his Left, ≈øhewed him too leave given to the Lying Spirit to per≈øwade him? v. 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23. Who I ≈øay of the≈øe were then mo≈øt Loyal (I wi≈øh it were not too much the Parallel of what ≈øeems to be doing in the World; for is it not (as may be ≈øeen in the Explication of the ≈øixth Vial, ch. 16. p. 127, 128.) by the three unclean Spirits coming out of the Mouth of the Dragon, of the Bea≈øt, and fal≈øe Prophet, that the Kings of the Earth, and of the whole World, are to be gathered to the Battle of that great day of God Almighty?) to their Prince? let the I≈ø≈øue ≈øpeak: who now the mo≈øt Faithful, who the mo≈øt Dutiful, the Event (it ≈øeems not to be far off,) may e're long declare.

Be≈øides, becau≈øe the in≈øinuating the want of Loyalty, and ju≈øt Reverence to Maje≈øty, is the likelie≈øt Engine to undermine the be≈øt of de≈øigns, (it was this Crucified our Lord him≈øelf, and gave the great hindrance to that Work he came into the World for, John 19. 12, 13. 'Twas this was the accu≈øation they charged his Di≈øciples with, Acts 17. 7. Acts 25. 7, 8. This too that every day robs Princes of the Services of the be≈øt of their Subjects; had I not long trod in Court, and ≈øeen the worthie≈øt of Men run down by ≈øuch Artifices, I ≈øhould not have ≈øo touched this Topick: But becau≈øe this ≈øo often happens, (the ba≈øe and unworthy have no other Arts to uphold them≈øelves by); let me beg Pardon (Mighty Princes) for it is your Intere≈øt is herein pur≈øued, if I farther repre≈øent to you in the Reigns of tho≈øe, who formerly ≈øate on the Thrones you do, who they were, who were ≈øtill the be≈øt Friends to Maje≈øty.

Whether tho≈øe fine Gentlemen who are always making their Court, the con≈øtant Attendants at the Levees and Couchees of their great Ma≈øters, ≈øtill pre≈ø≈øing on to be in the Eye of the Prince, and like the Sun-flower look gay, and hold up their Heads bravely, whil≈øt all ≈øhines on them, but as ≈øoon as the Shadows begin to appear, humbly made their Leg, begged their Conge, and with as good a Grace wheeled about to the Pre≈øence of the ri≈øing Sun, and it may be were as bu≈øy, and officious there, as if every one of them had been that Pho≈øphorus which opened the Day for their Ri≈øe. Were the≈øe now the better Subjects, or tho≈øe who when they ≈øaw the Storm approaching, in all Humility forewarned them of the Danger, but had nothing but the Bread of Affliction, and the Water of Affliction for it; like ≈øolitary Micaiah many times were ordered to Pri≈øon till they returned in Peace, though to return in Peace (had they hearkned to the de≈øpi≈øed Me≈ø≈øengers it might have been ≈øo,) was never their Lot: It was otherwi≈øe decreed, as in Ahab's Ca≈øe; and Micaiah, with all the Ignominy they ca≈øt on him, was in the mean time the Favourite of a much better Court, the Secretary of their greater Prince, of God him≈øelf, to declare it.

And now judge you (Dread Soveraign) whom you ought to pre≈øer in your Thoughts? Whether tho≈øe fal≈øe Sycophants, Men made to undo Princes and Courts, and then to de≈øert them; or tho≈øe who mu≈øt always be ≈øteddy, as that Truth, with which they are intru≈øted? Who cannot but do what in them lies to prevent tho≈øe changes, which the others are no farther concerned in, than to make good their Po≈øt in them who ever falls? Who really mourn for the Sins that bring them on, and whatever be the Fate of the Prince, make it ≈øo far their own, as to lament both his, and the Misfortunes of the
Publick, which cannot but ≈øuffer with him? Who is the be≈øt Subject, he who with his Prayers, with his Tears, with tho≈øe warnings he thinks he is in Con≈øcience-bound to Admini≈øter to you, follows you in every Change; Or he who cares not what becomes of your Per≈øons, your Crowns, your Kingdoms, your Souls, provided he can but ≈øecure that Mammon of ∆≤righteou≈øne≈øs, to which alone he is a true Homager?

For if it be not ≈øo, how hath it come to pa≈øs, that your Predece≈ø≈øors have been Betrayed, and Murthered ≈øome of them by their greate≈øt Favourites? Others, however adored whil≈øt living, ≈øo de≈øerted at their Deaths, as ≈øcarce to have found a charitable Hand to lay them in the Grave? and tho≈øe who have gone off the Stage with the greate≈øt applau≈øe, ≈øoon forgotten amid≈øt the gratulations and glories of the next Reign?

So unhappy of all Men are you in this, (Great Princes) and how almo≈øt ≈øhould it be otherwi≈øe? Such being the Arts by which Men ri≈øe, ≈øuch the de≈øigns of the Ambitious, (a name that is big with all that is ill,) ≈øo much fal≈øhood, ≈øo much Envy, ≈øo much Pride, ≈øo much Intemperance, ≈øo much (not to di≈ø≈øemble,) Vice of every ≈øort, that, like the mixt Multitude coming out of Egypt with the I≈øraelites, is always to be found in your Retinue: Not that this is, what is therefore pre≈øently to be reflected on your Maje≈øties, but on the Corruption of humane Nature, and tho≈øe great Bodies you govern, which like great Ve≈ø≈øels cannot be without great Dregs.

But this is ≈øtill your ∆≤nhappine≈øs, that you can make Men no better; that when you have imployed your be≈øt Care and Circum≈øpection, Mankind will be ≈øtill Mankind, and the wickedne≈øs of a fal≈øe Heart will not always be concealed.

Not that I would be ≈øo di≈ø-ingenuous, as not to acknowledge, what is due to tho≈øe brave and worthy Men, that have in all Ages been bred up in, or Retainers at Court; I know there were, and are the Saints in Cae≈øar's Hou≈øe, Philip. 4. 22. And it is great Pity, where Vertue and Honour are ≈øo much Profe≈ø≈øed, there ≈øhould be any others; it is great Pity, (for it is to you Chri≈øtian Princes this is chiefly addre≈ø≈øed) where Religion and the Go≈øpel are owned, what is ≈øo contrary to both ≈øhould be ≈øo much entertained; but mo≈øt of all unhappy, that Religion, that the Go≈øpel, at lea≈øt the high Preten≈øions to both, ≈øhould produce the≈øe Effects: For is not this the ca≈øe, that it is the Holy Man, the Confe≈ø≈øor, the Zealous Bigot, he that talks of nothing ≈øo much as of the Church, and the Veneration due to its Laws and Authority, who is the wor≈øt of Sycophants? Your Hi≈øtories will inform you, what your Royal Progenitors, and Predece≈ø≈øors have done for him; what the De≈øigns and Projects he hath put them upon; what the Dangers they have ≈øo often incurred, and how he hath returned the obligation, your ≈øelves are be≈øt able to Judge.

And what is it now at la≈øt he and his bu≈øy Agents require from you, as the Complement of that Zeal, that hath been ≈øo much abu≈øed? What is it they would requite all you have done for them with, but (let me u≈øe the Words of the Holy-Gho≈øt in the ≈øixth Vial, (under which I doubt not we now are) in gathering you to the Battle of that great day of God Almighty, Rev. 16. 14. That Battle in which none can engage and pro≈øper?
And let me upon the Pro≈øpect of what that portends, once more repeat it, Be wi≈øe now therefore, O ye Kings, be in≈øtructed ye Judges of the Earth.

But there are among you (Great Soveraigns) who ≈øeem not to be ≈øo much concerned in this; tho≈øe I mean, who having left the corrupt Communion of the Church of Rome, yet have not fully pur≈øued or acted agreeable to that Reformation, which is to bring on, or ≈øucceed the Fall of Babylon. To ≈øuch is it, I have to add, that they would
plea≈øe to con≈øider, it will not ≈øuffice, that you are contented to be called Prote≈øtants, and enjoy the Intere≈øt of that Name, unle≈øs you are what that Name ≈øpeaks: And it is your highe≈øt Concern ≈øo to be; the time growing on, when Succe≈øs and Victory ≈øhall go along with Truth and Piety.

Have you been ≈øo happy to throw off her Yoak, to di≈øclaim her Errors, to de≈øpi≈øe her ∆≤≈øurpations, let then none of her Principles, none of her Practices mix with your Politicks; act, (Glorious Princes,) act bravely and openly for God and that Religion you Pro≈øe≈øs; It is but to le≈ø≈øen your Strength, to think when God is doing his own Work, that nothing but the Arm of Fle≈øh can ≈øave you: Why ≈øhould you think he cannot defend his own Cau≈øe, without li≈øting his Enemies in the Service?

Is it not he, who hath ≈øaid, not by Might, nor by Power, but by my Spirit ≈øaith the Lord of Ho≈øts? Zechar. 4. 6. No, let Princes and People con≈øider, that it is the holine≈øs, and purity of Religion God will e≈øtabli≈øh in the World; let them con≈øider, how hitherto in all the ≈øignal Deliverances of his People, him≈øelf hath ≈øtept in, and a≈ø≈øerted the Glory of the Succe≈øs, and let them but reform to that Holine≈øs, that Purity, there needs no farther force to beat her down, for where the≈øe are, Babylon is fallen. Amen.

div.head: For the Reverend D. W.
div.p:
I Return you many Thanks not only for the Honour, but the benefit of peru≈øing your Learned Tract, and am ≈øorry I mu≈øt make ≈øo un≈øuitable a Requital, as to trouble you with my Excu≈øe for not Licen≈øing it: However, I hope when you have con≈øidered it, you will allow it to be rea≈øonable. I will not alledge, (though I might do it) that I have all along declined medling with Di≈øcour≈øes of this Nature, which have been offered me by tho≈øe, I had great rea≈øon to e≈øteem. But the Truth in ≈øhort is, that a large Book on this Subject, and a very accurate one, as I am told, was lately, not for the performance, but the Matters ≈øake, ≈øent back from hence without an Imprimatur. I believe you have hinted the rea≈øon out of St. Chry≈øo≈øtome, where he ≈øays that St. Paul would not plainly ≈øay, what the „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ

The predicting the Fall of the Roman Church now, may be as ungrateful tho≈øe, to who≈øe Intere≈øts are ingaged in it, as the foretelling the Ruin of the Roman Empire could be then, and the Ca≈øes being ≈øo like, it may perhaps be thought ≈øea≈øonable to ob≈øerve the ≈øame Rule that St. Paul then did. Sir, I hope you will take this freedom in good part from one, who to the utmo≈øt of his Power is de≈øirous to approve him≈øelf

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p:
WHAT it was that hath ≈øo long made the≈øe Animadver≈øions abortive, will appear by the Letter on the preceding Page; and therefore without any farther appeal to other Witne≈ø≈øes, to ≈øhew that what is here publi≈øhed, is no more done to ≈øerve a turn now, than it was then written for it; What I have to reque≈øt from every Beader, is, that it may be received with the ≈øame Sincerity with which it was fir≈øt Penned; which was in the retirement of a long Sickne≈øs, when I was ≈øeque≈øtred from my family, (the be≈øt part of it being upon other occa≈øions ab≈øent from me,) and had only God, and his good Spirit, and my own Con≈øcience to confer with; that Con≈øcience, which notwith≈øtanding the Prejudice with which ≈øome then, and ≈øince have loaded me, as if I had been le≈øs ≈øound in our Holy Reformed Religion, ≈øuffered me not then to temporize with tho≈øe who ≈øate at the Helm, (to the greate≈øt of whom, I could have had as ea≈øy acce≈øs, as any others of my Brethren,) that Con≈øcience I ≈øay, which ≈øuffered me not then to temporize, and I thank my God, makes me ≈øtill above all ≈øordid Flattery; and I de≈øire to ble≈øs his Holy Name, (I hope what I ≈øhall here publi≈øh will be the freer from all carnal Intere≈øt,)
who hath in his Providence made me in ≈øome degree a Martyr, both then, and now.

For if I have ≈øince ≈øuffered, as I am ≈øen≈øible I have, for being thought to be one whom my Great Ma≈øter then favoured, I ≈øuffered no le≈øs then, for being thought what I was, and ≈øhall always endeavour to acquit my ≈øelf therein, one of the mo≈øt firm and un≈øhaken Prote≈øtants: No, I am bold to ≈øay, whatever other Opinion that great Prince had of me, he never thought otherwi≈øe of me, than as one (let it be called Stiffne≈øs, Moro≈øene≈øs, Pride, or whatever other name ill Men have for tho≈øe, who turn not with every Wind, I am little ≈øollicitous) who knew neither how to di≈ø≈øemble or fawn. But whatever either then, or ≈øince hath befallen me, I have this to comfort my ≈øelf with, that nothing hath, nor I hope ever ≈øhall alienate my Zeal from that Truth, for which I have de≈øired always to appear: I have done it at Court, in the Univer≈øity, City, and where-ever el≈øe it lay in my way.

And if I had nothing el≈øe to plead for my Sincerity, I think the Dedication of that Sermon to his Maje≈øty, pre≈øented to him on that very Day, and at the very point of time, when the Zealous Bigots of the other Religion were hurrying him to his fir≈øt publick appearance at their Wor≈øhip, the Dedication I ≈øay of that Sermon alone, in which the Super≈øtitions of Rome, and the Impieties of the Je≈øuits, (who were then the prevailing Faction) are ≈øo highly declared again≈øt, might be alledged for a ≈øufficient proof; I am ≈øure it was what was mo≈øt heinou≈øly re≈øented by the Party, and the Author, (as appears by what was afterwards publi≈øhed again≈øt him, in a Pamphlet of theirs, called Good advice to the Pulpits, p. 61.) had the Honour to be fonnd in that good Company, to whieh none I think will deny the ≈øtile of the Be≈øt of Prote≈øtants. But if the Cry be once rai≈øed, what's mi≈øtaken at
Court, ≈øhall be doubly ≈øo in the City, and from thence ≈øoon ecchoed into the Country, and the mo≈øt innocent Per≈øon forthwith made the mark of popular Outrage; for it is but dre≈ø≈øing up the Martyr in Bea≈øts Skins, and every dog will be ≈ønarling and barking at him: nay, even tho≈øe, who in their great Under≈øtanding know not what it is to be Papi≈øt, or Prote≈øtant, nay, would it may be, be hard put to it, if they were to prove in what it is them≈øelves are di≈øtingui≈øhed even from Brutes, ≈øhall however in their great Zeal run away with the Cry, as if they were the only Skilled Profe≈ø≈øors in Divinity, and Men who have ≈øpent all their time in hard Study, and made it their Bu≈øine≈øs to live up to that Divinity they profe≈øs, ≈øhall not be thought worthy to offer Sen≈øe or Rea≈øon to ≈øuch mighty Sophies.

And if after all, they chance to find their Error, what is the Amends is to be made for all, beyond this? That the Per≈øon they thus run on, is the mo≈øt mi≈øtaken Man in the World! But who bid them thus mi≈øtake, who bid them fir≈øt take up an Error, and then u≈øe all the rudene≈øs untaught nature is guilty of, to defend it?

But what mu≈øt a Man ≈øay then, to remove ≈øuch a Scandal? Will it avail to ≈øay I Sucked in the greate≈øt dete≈øtation of Popery with my Mothers milk, that ever ≈øince I was able to u≈øe my Tongue, I forbore not to do it in the abhorrence of its Super≈øtitions, and Idolatries? Will, if nothing el≈øe, this following Treati≈øe ≈øay any thing for its Author in this matter? VVhat ≈øhall I take (O Po≈øterity judge thou of this depraved Age, wherein ≈øuch Apologies are needful!) to te≈øtifie the indignation I cannot but have to be thus Traduced? A favourer of Popery! Do I believe a Hell, a Devil? Let Popery and the≈øe be loved at once! No, be it not my Pre≈øumption, O my God, but thy Grace that draws the
Profe≈ø≈øion from me) may I, if ever Thou bringe≈øt the Wheel over thy People in this Nation, be the fir≈øt Witne≈øs in this thy great Cau≈øe.

But I am a≈øhamed there ≈øhould be occa≈øion for any thing of this Nature, nor ≈øhould I have troubled the VVorld with it, were it not, that tho≈øe who appear in Print, at the ≈øame time ≈øet them≈øelves up, as Marks to be ≈øhot at, every one ≈øpending his Verdict, and accepting, or rejecting the VVork, according to the re≈øpect he hath for the Author.

But mo≈øt e≈øpecially thus it happens in Subjects of this nature; for how can any one pretend to, or hope that the VVorld ≈øhould believe, that be entirely gives up him≈øelf (and yet certainly without it, there can be but little probability of his ≈øteering well in it,) to the conduct of Heaven, if at the ≈øame time he hath any covert Di≈ø≈øimulation, not to ≈øay Coldne≈øs in the Argument, whereof he treats?

Can a Papi≈øt in Ma≈øquerade (≈øucceding Ages will wonder at the Stile) decry Popery, di≈øcover all the abominations of it, fix the Judgment declared again≈øt it, and be≈øatisfied that the ≈øeven la≈øt Plagues are but ≈øo many degrees of that Ruin, which is foretold to belong to the Bea≈øt? The≈øe I think are Incongruities, that no wi≈øe, no good Man can imagine to be con≈øi≈øtent, and therefore taking for granted that all is defamation, and but the effects of downright Malice, and Ignorance; I will ≈øuppo≈øe the veil to be taken off, the Cloud vani≈øhed, and my ≈øelf to be a much better Prote≈øtant than tho≈øe, who out of de≈øign, or from the want of being better informed, have rai≈øed, or entertained the Scandal.

It may not be altogether improper to mention to whom the Dedication was fir≈øt intended, and that was to my gracious Ma≈øter, King James the Second, (who≈øe late Royal Favours towards me po≈ø≈øibly might be one Rea≈øon, why that Scandal I have been wiping off, was ca≈øt upon me; but no
time ought to blot out my grateful Sen≈øe of what was de≈øigned, though without effect as well as without my ≈øeeking it,) And I hope it may ≈øtill find that good effect with him, (if it hath the lot to come to his Royal Hands) which his mo≈øt humble, and Duti≈øul Servant and Subject then de≈øigned it to; I am ≈øure he knows in his highe≈øt Pro≈øperity, I never was of tho≈øe who flattered his Greatne≈øs, and I am ≈øure he hath that good Opinion of me, to believe that in his Troubles, I never can be a Shimei. And therefore my Hopes are, he will in the fir≈øt place judge me Sincere in that Loyalty I owe to him who is King of Kings, and in the ≈øecond, I owe to tho≈øe who rule under him, to whom I am ≈øure I could never have aquitted my ≈øelf, had I not (which is the bu≈øine≈øs of this Treati≈øe) repre≈øented Rome in its true Colours to them; that Rome which hath ≈øo long u≈øurpt upon their Royalties, and can no longer ≈øub≈øi≈øt, than by the diminution of their Maje≈øties, they contribute to it.

I now proceed to ≈øpeak of the Work it ≈øelf, the occa≈øion whereof is be≈øt ≈øeen by the Title Page; and whether, and how far it hath an≈øwered its Title will appear by that time the Reader ≈øhall have peru≈øed its Contents, in which I hope he will not think his Time altogether lo≈øt; many of the notions he ≈øhall there find being wholy new, and what none el≈øe hitherto hath touched at, and all of them coherent as between them≈øelves, ≈øo with the whole: And if ≈øometimes more than one ≈øingle Event be offered for the Explication, or rather Illu≈øtration of the re≈øpective Points, I think that is a liberty of Prophe≈øying, (let me ≈øo expre≈øs it) no good, or wi≈øe Man will Condemn, as being but agreeable to that variety of Sen≈øe, in which all allow the Scripture to abound: Be≈øides, were it only for the re≈øre≈øhing the Reader, that a Variety is ≈øometimes given, it is certainly what at lea≈øt might be excu≈øed,
that his Curio≈øity and Plea≈øure are but hereby ≈øerved.

And as for the Author of Nubes Te≈øtium, who≈øe Preface chiefly occa≈øioned the≈øe Reflections, I hope he will not look upon it as an improper An≈øwer to his whole Book, to ≈øhew how tho≈øe Corruptions we blame in the Romi≈øh Church came in; how the Romi≈øh Church it ≈øelf grew to that heighth, at which it is, or hath been in any time of the Reign of Antichri≈øt; for what will it avail to urge Authorities of Fathers, Men ≈øubject to Errors as our ≈øelves, for tho≈øe Corruptions, (were they in their te≈øtimony all with him) if it be proved, that tho≈øe points he brings them to confirm, are part of tho≈øe Corruptions, for which ≈øhe is ≈øo highly to be Condemned?

I would do all the Right imaginable to Antiquity, but there's a great difference between what bears the title of ≈øuch, and what really is true Antiquity. The Fathers them≈øelves have they not been corrupted by the crafty Forgeries of temporizing Hypocrites? Or if they had not been corrupted, is it not enough to abate their Credit, that in what the Author brings them again≈øt us, they either differ from them≈øelves in other parts of their Writings, or, what is much more, they differ from the Holy Scripture? The Holy Scripture I ≈øay, which mu≈øt be allowed to be the Judge in this Ca≈øe.

Nor will it ≈øerve their Turn, what they u≈øually an≈øwer us with here, that by giving thus much to Scripture, and making every one Judge of the Sen≈øe of it, we put all upon the I≈ø≈øue of a private Spirit: For we make no private Per≈øon any more a Judge here, than they do; we ≈øuppo≈øe to be able to reach the ≈øen≈øe of Scripture, all means mu≈øt be u≈øed for the attaining it; only this we are ≈øure, whether this, or the other Per≈øon hit it, or no, yet it is the true ≈øen≈øe of Scripture ought to prevail beyond the
Authority of Councils, Fathers, or any other Doctors whatever. And whatever the Per≈øon be, who is ≈øo happy as to ≈øhew mo≈øt Rea≈øon for the Sen≈øe he gives of it, this is He, who≈øe Opinion ought to obtain.

'Tis true indeed, with re≈øpect to any private Per≈øon, at the fir≈øt View, the names of Councils, and Fathers, and the like, ≈øeem to carry with them a notion of what is more publick, in Oppo≈øition to a private Spirit; but all this is but Fallacy, and no way the Inference, that ought to be made from that which is urged in this matter, viz. That no Prophe≈øy of the Scripture is of any private Interpretation, Pet. 2. 1. 20. For that is not the meaning of that Place, that one Per≈øon is more private than two, than a whole Council, than all ancient Writers whatever; but that he, and they too are Private, and their Interpretation is ≈øuch, if it agree not with the Analogy of Scripture, and the ≈øen≈øe of the Holy Spirit him≈øelf: 'Tis this Sen≈øe, taking it without re≈øpect to any Per≈øons, makes it not to be private; and ≈øo the antithe≈øis there lies, for the Prophecy came not in old time by the Will of Man; But Holy Men of God ≈øpake, as they were moved by the Holy-Gho≈øt. It is not the Will of Man, the Decrees of Councils, the Sentiments of Fathers, the pretended Infallibility of any Chair, (all this is but the Will of Man,) if they concur not with what the Holy-Gho≈øt hath ≈øpoken.

And as for what I differ from others in, who have given up them≈øelves to the ≈øame ≈øort of Studies, I hope it will not be imputed ≈øo much to an affected Singularity, as to the force of Truth; I having indu≈øtriou≈øly avoided to con≈øult the Hypothe≈øes, or Explications of others, whil≈øt this was Writing, that ≈øo I might not be drawn to lean to any humane Authority, and ≈øerved my ≈øelf only with ≈øuch general Notions, as were before imprinted on my Mind, without any particular applying my ≈øelf to ≈øuch, who might
have been apt to lead me. The Reverend Mr. Mede's Writings I confe≈øs I had long ≈øince been acquainted with, and Napeir's ingenious and methodical Treati≈øe, I had many Years ago peru≈øed, and was extreamly quickned by them to a de≈øire of being better acquainted with the≈øe excellent My≈øteries; Brightman I had not ≈øo great a Reverence for, and therefore in a manner wholly declined ≈øpending any of my Thoughts or Time on him; and as for any thing that is more Modern, I ≈øtudiou≈øly declined it, as not being willing to tincture the Gla≈øs, through which I hoped to take the Pro≈øpect of ≈øo fair a Country. Only Mon≈øieur Jurieu's Books I could not well avoid the peru≈øing, they being in the hands of an Ingenious, and Learned Prote≈øtant French Mini≈øter, who then did me the favour of ≈øpending ≈øome time with me at my Hou≈øe, and would be often ≈øpeaking of him; to him I had communicated ≈øome of my Thoughts on the≈øe matters, and had the opportunity of di≈øcour≈øing over ≈øome of the Arguments of Mon≈øienr Jurieu's Chapters, particularly that of his ≈øeventh Chapter, Tom. 1. Concerning the number of the Bea≈øt, in which I could no way agree with that worthy Per≈øon, as I could neither with Potter, or any other I have met with on that Argument, upon which occa≈øion I wrote the≈øe following Reflections in the Margin of the Book, he put into my Hands, which I ≈øhall give in the ≈øame Words I then wrote them.

I am afraid le≈øt this mo≈øt learned Man in this whole Chapter hath ≈øuffered him≈øelf to be drawn away by Conjectures that are too uncertain; and therefore without replying any thing thereto, I leave it to be enquired, whether the whole Matter may not rather be referred to Hildebrand or Gregory the ≈øeventh, in whom ≈øeems to be fulfilled, whatever Paul in his Epi≈øtle to the The≈ø≈øalonians
2. 2. 3. &c. hath foretold of the Man of Sin, or the Son of Perdition; and that we no way doubt but that he is there de≈øigned, the Holy-Gho≈øt as it were points with the Finger at it, Rev. 13. 10. He that leadeth into Captivity, ≈øhall go into Captivity, he that killeth with the Sword, mu≈øt be killed with the Sword. Here is the Patience and the Faith of the Saints: which he likewi≈øe thus prefaces, v. 9. If any Man have an Ear let him hear. And why all this, unle≈øs it were ≈øome great thing he thereby pointed at? But what great thing, but the leading him into Captivity, who led into Captivity? But who was it, who led into Captivity, but the Roman Emperor, who him≈øelf, at the taking of Rome, which happened in the Year of Chri≈øt 410, (Honorius then being Emperor in the We≈øt,) may be under≈øtood to be led into Captivity? Then it was Alaricus King of the Goths, took Rome, after which time the Roman Empire began to be ≈øo le≈ø≈øened, that nothing thereof be≈øides the Name and Shadow was left remaining; ≈øince which time, as the Apo≈øtle had foretold, he being taken away who hindred, the Man of Sin, and Son of Perdition began to be revealed: Now from the Revealing of him, reckon 666, which the Holy-Gho≈øt ≈øaith is the number of a Man, as well as of the Bea≈øt (whereby the chief Empires were long ago de≈øigned by Daniel,) and you will come upon the fourth Year of Hildebrand, or Gregory the Seventh, viz. of Chri≈øt 1076, in which he fir≈øt Excommunicated the Emperor, and arrogated to him≈øelf the Power of con≈øtituting the Emperors: See the number of a Man, i. e. of him who by humane Craft and Wi≈ødom did thus advance him≈øelf and his Succe≈ø≈øors? ≈øee him ri≈øing up to his full Maturity, ≈øee him al≈øo giving Power to the fir≈øt Bea≈øt! For now it was the Emperor obtained that Power from the Pope, which he ever after exerci≈øed, Rev. 13. 12. But ≈øee only the Image of Power re≈øtored to him, ver. 14. for from that time the Emperor recovered a full and ab≈øolute Empire; or ≈øee the Image of the Empire transferred to the Popes, i. e. them, after the likene≈øs of the Emperors, enjoying full Empire, and arrogating what we read, ver. 15, 16, 17. &c. whereas it is added, ver. 18. Here is Wi≈ødom. Are we not again bid to ob≈øerve ≈øome great and eminent thing? And what is it is ≈øo, but that on which the Hinge of the whole Apocalyp≈øe turns? And in what can this be more than in the ≈øearching out, and declaring that great Antichri≈øt? Would you again know whence the Ri≈øe of Antichri≈øt de≈øigned in its Maturity by the number of 666, is to be taken, turn to Rev. 12. where the Enmity of the Dragon, i. e. the Roman Pagan Empire again≈øt Chri≈øt, and his Religion, his War, and its I≈ø≈øue are de≈øcribed, which a little before the end of the Chapter, the Earth, i. e. The Earthly Power is ≈øaid to have helped. Now this happened when the Emperors by their decrees aboli≈øhed Here≈øies, (i. e. That River, which the Serpent is ≈øaid to have ca≈øt out of his Mouth after the Woman flying into the Wilderne≈øs,) with which he would have corrupted the Church; which I cannot tell, whether it may not be well applied to the times of Con≈øtantine, who fir≈øt re≈øtored Peace to the Church, or el≈øe to the General Councils, ≈øummoned by the Power of the Emperors, whereby tho≈øe ≈øo enormous Here≈øies were Condemned; which time, if it exceeds the time of the taking of Rome, and ≈øo doth n ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ altogether agree with the Ri≈øe of Antichri≈øt, it is to be ob≈øerved that that happened hence, viz. Becau≈øe it was to extend it ≈øelf to the flight of the Woman into the Wilderne≈øs, which
is Contemporary with the Reign of Antichri≈øt. This, however it dropped from my running Pen, I pre≈øume to give as I then ≈øet it down, and as it will appear to be the great Hinge, on which all turns in the Explication of the Apocalyptical Writings, and what I have pur≈øued in the following Di≈øcour≈øe.

I rea≈øoned al≈øo with the ≈øame Per≈øon, viz. Mon≈øieur De≈øgalle≈ønierres, formerly Mini≈øter of Mans in France, now of one of the French Churches in We≈øtmin≈øter, on ≈øome other Heads, in which I found my ≈øelf ≈øo much to differ from that Excellent Per≈øon (his worthy Countryman Mon≈øieur Jurieu I mean,) particularly as to the ≈øen≈øe of the fir≈øt Vial, which he makes to con≈øi≈øt in the Corruptions that then broke forth in the Romi≈øh Church, whereas I am apt to think, it ought rather to be applied to the Plague that was ≈øent as the Puni≈øhment of ≈øuch Corruptions, in the Irruptions of the Saracens: As al≈øo in the fourth, ≈øixth, and ≈øeventh Vial, I cannot but differ from that great Man, as may be ≈øeen in the following di≈øcour≈øe; that I fall in with him in the ≈øecond, and third, is but agreeable to my Notion on the fir≈øt, in which if the Saracens infe≈øted the men that had the mark of the Bea≈øt in their own Country, the men that had the mark of the Brea≈øt are in judgment permitted to attempt the revenging the Injury in the Country, or Territories of the Saracens, under the ≈øecond and third Vial. And if in the ≈øame time, I farther offer the great Plague that the Walden≈øes, and Albigen≈øes at that time were to tho≈øe who had the mark of the Bea≈øt, I hope 'twill be no darkning of knowledge, to leave it to the choice of the Reader, which he thinks fitte≈øt to pitch on.

That I have con≈øulted with other Authors, ≈øuch as the Fathers, Hi≈øtories, Councils, and other Writers,
that was but nece≈ø≈øary for the informing my ≈øelf of the State of the Romi≈øh Church, the Romi≈øh, Greek, and Mahometan Empires, with the Hi≈øtories of the ≈øeveral Princes, and Countries in any of the≈øe, in order to the knowledge of tho≈øe great Events and Circum≈øtances of all ≈øorts, that might conduce to the Explaining the≈øe Important Truths: But that I have not every where mention'd my Authorities, was at pre≈øent to ea≈øe my ≈øelf, and the Reader, as not knowing, but that a di≈øcour≈øe of this nature, if it ≈øhould happen to find acceptance in the World, might draw farther enlargements from me hereafter; in which it would be requi≈øite to be more exact as to the Quotations.

There are I confe≈øs ≈øome other Di≈øcour≈øes on this Subject, which I cannot ≈øay I have not ≈øeen, though it was long after I had in effect fini≈øhed this Treati≈øe, and as I before ≈øaid, I was unwilling to peru≈øe any thing that might Prejudice, or be a Bar to my own free Thoughts; and it is but late that they came into my Hands, and that upon the occa≈øion of ≈øome Notions communicated by me to the Learned, and my worthy Friend, Mon≈øieur Allix, who thereupon ≈øpoke to me of Dr. Cre≈ø≈øener's, and Mr. Beverly's Books, both of them very ingenious Men, but utterly differing in their notions from what I here pre≈øent: As al≈øo he hath given me very high Expectations of what the profoundly learned Bi≈øhop of St. A≈øaph hath, or is preparing on the≈øe Subjects, but found me ≈øtill under that Stiffne≈øs, that believing what I have here written to be of a Piece, I was unwilling ≈øo much to be acquainted with what that Excellent Prelate hath to make the World happy with, when he ≈øhall plea≈øe to make it publick. Only having as I before ≈øaid, received Mr. Beverly's Book, I could not but be very much plea≈øed to find him, though upon different Grounds from what I go on, fix in a manner the ≈øame Period
for the Ruin of Antichri≈øt, he fixing it in 1697, without ≈øaying what part of the Year it is in which he fixes it, whereas my Computation makes it to be either in the later end of 1696, or the middle of 1697, for I place it in 1697, and a half after the ≈øub≈øtraction of the odd Days in the different Computations, or if the fraction of Hours be taken out about the end of 1696, no great difference of Calculation, though the Foundation on which we go be altogether different. And I cannot but adhere to my own, his notion of the Months ≈øpoken of in the Prophe≈øie, being Jewi≈øh Months, ≈øeeming to be a little precarious, and the number he ≈øets of 475, not being ≈øo proper to the time of the ten Kings or Horns ri≈øing up, as 455, or thereabout, on which I pitch. For though on the ≈øuppo≈øition he goes, it may well enough point to the Ce≈ø≈øation of the Empire, it will not ≈øo well agree to the ri≈øe of the Bea≈øt, and the ten Horns with it.

But I will not too much controvert the matter with that Zealous Per≈øon, I cannot but rejoice to ≈øee his A≈ø≈øurance that the Event will Corre≈øpond with his Calculation, nor can I be di≈ø≈øatisfied that it falls in with mine.

I ≈øhall not need to ≈øay much more by way of Preface, only I wi≈øh his particular Applications to any private Prince may not be as far from the Mark as Mr. Mede's was of Gu≈øtavus Adolphus. But it may be, for I would le≈ø≈øen no Man's Labours on this Argument, what is ≈øeverally, and in ≈øo different a manner performed by us, may be but like ≈øeveral Arrows ≈øhot by ≈øeveral Hands at the ≈øame Mark; if we all, or any of us hit, may that which ought to be the Mark of all our Studies, Crown all, viz. The Glory of him, who is the God of Prophe≈øie, and who, if he commanded St. John in one
place to Seal tho≈øe things which the ≈øeven Thunders, uttered, and write them not, as being ob≈øcure and my≈øterious, and to be kept as ≈øuch when fir≈øt revealed, Rev. 10. 4. Hath likewi≈øe commanded in another, not to ≈øeal the Sayings of the Prophe≈øie of this Book: for THE TIME IS AT HAND. Revel. 22. 10. Amen, Amen.

div.head: Introduction.
div.p: WHEN I fir≈øt entred on this Work, I had it in my thoughts to have replied both to Preface and Book, but through a very great and long Indi≈øpo≈øition in Health, I was not able to make that ≈øpeed I intended in the De≈øign, and was greatly plea≈øed to find my ≈øelf prevented in ≈øeveral parts of it, by the Learned Pens of tho≈øe who had ≈øo ≈øucce≈øsfully ingaged therein: Nor did I que≈øtion, (what hath ≈øince happen'd) but that a very little time would produce a full an≈øwer to every thing that was material, in the whole Collection, though ≈øhould there not have been a Syllable more offered in the Controver≈øie, than what the Author had given me occa≈øion to ≈øpeak to from the Preface, I am apt to think, there would be little rea≈øon to boa≈øt his Monuments of Antiquity; the Gibeoniti≈øh Craft of old Sacks upon their A≈ø≈øes, of old and rent Wine-bottles, of old and clouted Shooes, of old Garments, and dry and mouldy Bread: Jo≈øhua 9. 4, 5. whereby ('tis ea≈øie to make out the Allu≈øion) tho≈øe, for whom he writes, are ≈øo much concern'd to hide all their Cheats, will be but a poor proof of their coming from a far Country (let me ≈øo expre≈øs the remote and di≈øtant Ages of the Church) unle≈øs they bring with them, what the Gibeonites did not, Truth and Sincerity.

For is there not ≈øome Standard by which Antiquity it ≈øelf mu≈øt be tryed? For however, error can never be quid primum, yet it may be quid antiquum; we know it is as ancient, as the Fall of Man: Nay, more than that, as the Fall of Lucifer: So that the pretence of Antiquity alone, were all granted which is brought for ≈øuch, would not be ≈øufficient to e≈øtabli≈øh matters in Debate, unle≈øs what is urged as antiquum, or what is ancient, be proved likewi≈øe to be primum or fir≈øt, i. e. to be
the ≈øame with that Truth, which obtain'd, before the Ancients either glo≈ø≈øed on, or witne≈ø≈øed to it; which whither it be or no; will appear by that time we ≈øhall have reflected on the Preface.

To begin therefore where the Author doth, viz. That Novelty in Faith is ≈øo great a ≈øcandal to any that lay claim to the Truth of Chri≈øtianity, that where≈øoever it is effectually proved, there all pretences immediately fall to the ground, and there can be no Truth in that Society, be≈øide the noi≈øe of it, and the Name, I am very ready to grant, and ≈øhall only con≈øider, that we may come plainly to the matter in Debate, the≈øe two things.
1. What Novelty in Faith is?
2. Whether the Collection of the Primitive Fathers giving Te≈øtimony to the Faith, once delivered to the Saints, as 'tis here pretended, will ju≈øtifie tho≈øe, the Author pleads for, from Novelty?

div.head: CHAP. I. What Novelty in Faith is?
div.p:
1. NOvelty in Faith is, what≈øoever is brought in, how early ≈øoever it be, contrary to the Rule of Faith, as once delivered to the Saints, i. e. to the Holy Church, as then E≈øtabli≈øht in its Purity, and Perfection by Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles: For that is what mu≈øt be under≈øtood by that Phra≈øe, as 'tis found, Jude v. 3. it being the greate≈øt ab≈øurdity to imagine, that the Apo≈øtle ≈øhould ≈øpeak, as he there doth, of his giving all diligence to write unto them that were Sanctified of the common Salvation, or exhort them earne≈øtly to contend for the Faith, which was once delivered unto the Saints, if the nece≈ø≈øary Principles of that Salvation, had not been already made common, ≈øufficiently given forth, and publi≈øht; or the Faith it ≈øelf not fully delivered, for which they were ≈øo earne≈øtly to contend. I am ≈øure St. Paul thought ≈øo, when he exhorted Timothy, 2 Tim. 1. 13. to hold fa≈øt the form of ≈øound words
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the model, or delineation, the ≈øhort pre≈øcript, and certain Rule of whol≈øome Doctrine, he had heard of him, and more at large, in the third Chapter of the ≈øame Epi≈øtle,
v. 14, 15, 16, 17. required him to continue in the things which he had learned, and been a≈ø≈øured of, knowing of whom he had learned them, and that from a Child be had known the holy Scriptures, which were able to make him wi≈øe to Salvation, through Faith which is in Je≈øus Chri≈øt: All Scripture is given by in≈øpiration of God, and is profitable for Doctrine, for Reproof, for Correction, for In≈øtruction in Righteou≈øne≈øs, that the Man of God may be perfect, throughly furni≈øht unto all good Works: And St. Peter prefers its Evidence before any Collection of Te≈øtimonies what≈øoever; for he prefers the Evidence of the written Word before a voice from Heaven, 2 Pet. 1. 19. For we have a more ≈øure Word of Prophe≈øie, whereunto you do well that you take heed, as unto a light that ≈øhineth in a dark place, until the day dawn, and the Day-Star ari≈øe in your hearts, knowing this first, that no Prophe≈øie of the Scripture is of any private Interpretation, for the Prophe≈øie came not at any time by the Will of Man, but holy men of God ≈øpake, as they were moved by the Holy Gho≈øt. To the≈øe, we may add St. John ≈øpeaking of it, As what they, i. e. the Christians had heard from the beginning, 1 Joh. 2. 24. What was the word of life, 1 Joh. 1. 1. what was theTruth, 1 Joh. 1. 8. But we have a better Witne≈øs than all the≈øe, even our Lord him≈øelf promi≈øing his Apo≈øtles before he left them, that the Spirit of Truth ≈øhould guide them into all Truth, John 16. 13. i. e. as him≈øelf enlarges it, chap. 14. 26. ≈øhould teach them all things, and bring all things to their remembrance, what≈øoever he had ≈øaid unto them: And as it is in that forecited, Joh. 16. 13. ≈øhould ≈øhew them things to come; which, what was it, but to a≈ø≈øure them, that what≈øoever was needful to be known either of the Precepts or My≈øteries of the Go≈øpel; what≈øoever for the comfort of the Church was needful to be foretold, ≈øhould be th ‚Ä¢ rowly reveal'd to them: Nothing, that was matter either of Faith or Practice, ≈øhould be left to uncertainties; the Spirit, which was to come down in ≈øo miraculous a manner, as he did on the Apo≈øtles on the day of Penteco≈øt, would declare to them the wholewill of God; would not leave them as Orphans, without ≈øufficient in≈øtructions in the Go≈øpel they were to Preach, without comfort and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in tho≈øe things they were to ≈øuffer as Martyrs for it.
And was not this effectually wrought by him? For
1. What are the Go≈øpels, but the things that Chri≈øt did and taught, brought to their Remembrance?

2. What the Epistles written by St. Paul, and others of the Apo≈øtles, but the teaching them all things, fully informing them, and by them the Church, in all matters of Faith and good Life, which were le≈øs clearly laid down in the Go≈øpels?

3. What the Revelation of St. John, with tho≈øe other Predictions ≈øcattered abroad in the Writings of the other Apo≈øtles, but the ≈øhewing them things to come? And if ≈øo: If there were ≈øo full a di≈øcovery of Truth made to the Apo≈øtles, that all that our Lord promi≈øed herein, was actually made good to them, whil≈øt in their Mini≈øtry here on Earth, and by them to the Church, which is, and can be built only upon the Foundation of the Apo≈øtles and Prophets, Je≈øus Chri≈øt him≈øelf being the chief corner Stone, Ephe≈ø. 2. 20. If not only St. Peter, 2 Epi≈øt. 3. 2. makes this the whole of the Chri≈øtian to be mindful of the words, which were ≈øpoken before by the Holy Prophets, and of the Commandment of them the Apo≈øtles of the Lord and Saviour: But St. Jude him≈øelf, (from whom the Author takes the Argument of his Collection, as 'tis to give Te≈øtimony to the Faith once delivered to the Saints) v. 17. gives this as his weighty Caution, that they ≈øhould remember the words, which were ≈øpoken before of the Apo≈øtles of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, 'twill leave it beyond all doubt, what 'tis we are to under≈øtand by Novelty in Faith, viz. What≈øoever hath at any time, ≈øince the Delivery of the Go≈øpel, and Sealing the Canon of Scripture, (for 'tis that, as hath been ≈øhew'd, which mu≈øt contain the Faith once delivered to the Saints) been broacht contrary to the ≈øound Doctrine therein contain'd: For 'tis not a Day, or a Year, or an Age, or indeed, ever ≈øo many Ages, make the difference; that's as much a Novelty in Faith, which any way tended to the corrupting of it in the Apo≈øtles days, as what hath ever ≈øince tended to the ≈øame, be it 15 Ages after, or in any Age whatever the World hath to continue.

The My≈øtery of Inquity which did then already work, when St. Paul wrote to the The≈ø≈øalonians, 2 Epi≈øt. 2. 7. was a Novelty in Faith, as well as when in all the degrees of it, it ≈øhould be fini≈øht in the time of Anti-chri≈øt: And it is but the ≈øame Novelty continued, and improved by the Devil, and his In≈øtruments, that hath in every Age ≈øet up it ≈øelf again≈øt God, v. 4. i. e. How different ≈øoever the ways have been, which it hath wrought; How various ≈øoever, and multiform the Errors, which have been levelled again≈øt Truth, all are but the ≈øeveral Heads of the
≈øame Hydra, the ≈øame Mon≈øter multiplying and increa≈øing again≈øt all the Endeavours of tho≈øe, who have at any time ≈øet them≈øelves to re≈øi≈øt the Innovation, i. e. To contend for the Faith once delivered to the Saints.
Which being ob≈øerved with re≈øpect to the ≈øtating what Novelty in Faith is, 'tis to be enquired in the ≈øecond place,

2. Whether the Collection of the Primitive Fathers, giving Te≈øtimony to the Faith once delivered to the Saints, as 'tis here pretended, will ju≈øtifie that Society, the Author pleads for, from Novelty? Now this will farther branch it ≈øelf into a twofold Enquiry, viz.
1. How far the Authority of the Fathers, ≈øimply con≈øider'd, ought to obtain in Matters of Faith? And,
2. How far, allowing the utmo≈øt that can be to their Authority, 'twill be for their Service, whom they are here brought to countenance?

div.head: CHAP. II. How far the Authority of the Fathers, ≈øimply con≈øider'd, ought to obtain in Matters of Faith?
div.p: 1. AS to the Authority of the Fathers, ≈øimply con≈øidered, there's nothing more certain, than that that can obtain no farther, than what they ≈øpeak is agreeable to the Faith they are brought to atte≈øt. For, 'tis not to make Faith, or to add to the Articles of it, that they are produc'd; 'tis only to witne≈øs to what was once delivered, and if they Speak not according to this word, it is becau≈øe there is no light in them, I≈øaiah 8. 20. And if ≈øo, 'twill be of little moment on who≈øe ≈øide they ≈øpeak: I ≈øay not this to di≈øcredit tho≈øe great names, which have ≈øo long been renown'd in the World, let them have all that is due to men of that Exemplary Piety and Abilities they were of, but let them have no more: No more, then them≈øelves ever pretended to, or what in the rea≈øon of the thing can belong to them: As for the purpo≈øe.

Can we imagine that they ever pretended, or that in Rea≈øon, their atte≈øting ought ≈øhould alter the nature of what they are brought to atte≈øt? In the particular matter in debate, will their a≈ø≈øerting it make that to be Truth, which before was Error?
Will their a≈ø≈øerting that the Invocation of Saints in Heaven is profitable and convenient?

p.hi: That there's a re≈øpect and Veneration due to their Relicts?

div.p: Will their a≈ø≈øerting that praying for the Souls departed, is advantageous to them, and was the practice of the Primitive Church?

Will their a≈ø≈øerting that in the ble≈ø≈øed Sacrament is contain'd the true, real, ≈øub≈øtantial Body of Chri≈øt, the ≈øub≈øtance of the Bread and Wine being converted into the true ≈øub≈øtance of Chri≈øt's Body and Blood, make all the≈øe things to be ≈øound, and Orthodox? if in the mean time from the Letter of Scripture, and the Analogy of Faith therein contain'd, it ≈øhall be made to appear that mo≈øt of the≈øe things are highly Super≈øtitious, if not Idolatrous! Or to join I≈ø≈øue on ≈øo much of the other heads, as can concern the points of Controver≈øie at pre≈øent under Debate (if at all it doth concern them)

Will their a≈ø≈øerting that Chri≈øt built his Church upon Peter, &c. If that were to the ends they pretend, advance Him or his Succe≈ø≈øors to any higher Title, or Dignity, than Chri≈øt him≈øelf gave him in his Go≈øpel?
Will their a≈ø≈øerting that Traditions are to be received, &c. though all brought under that head, no way reaches the pre≈øent Controver≈øie about Traditions?

Will their a≈ø≈øerting, la≈øtly, that the making the ≈øign of the Cro≈øs, the keeping Images of Chri≈øt, and his Saints was the practice of the Primitive Church, be a Rea≈øon, either why Traditions ≈øhould be of equal Authority with the Scripture, or the ≈øign of the Cro≈øs, or Images ≈øhould have Divine Honour paid to them? For otherwi≈øe, they come not up to what is at pre≈øent under Debate: Though had they ≈øaid all this (for I am contented he make the be≈øt of his Argument) what is this, or whatever el≈øe they would have the Fathers ≈øpeak for them, if at the ≈øame time they ≈øpeak again≈øt them≈øelves? i. e. again≈øt what they have deliver'd directly contrary to it, in any other of their writings; And what is much more, again≈øt

De l'onction & ton≈øure ≈øuper≈øtitieu≈øe des pretres & Moines & de ≈øes effets. croyent & e≈øperent participer √† la verit√© des offices Pa≈øtoraux, & des Cures, pourveu ≈øeulement qu'ils ≈øoient tondues comme agneaux, & oincts comme parois, & ≈øoient benits en touchant le livre & le calice avec la main, ils publient qu'ils ≈øont ordonn√©s Sacrificateurs comme il faut. div.head: CHAP. VI. How long this Eclip≈øe the Church, or at lea≈øt great part of it, was to ≈øuffer, was to continue?
div.p: IN an≈øwer to this Enquiry, it mu≈øt be con≈øider'd, that the Ri≈øe and Growth of Antichri≈øt mu≈øt be taken in, to make up the full Period; For 'tis not concerning his Continuance, or Duration after he came to his Maturity, but concerning the whole time, or Age of Antichri≈øt, that we here put the Que≈øtion:

And both the ≈øame with 42 Months, the time allotted for the giving the outward Court of the Temple to the Gentiles, and for the Holy Cities to be trodden under foot, Rev. 11. 2. Which is but another Explication of the reign of Antichri≈øt; As al≈øo is that thou≈øand two hundred and three≈øcore days a≈ø≈øign'd to the two Witne≈ø≈øes to Prophe≈øie in Sackcloth; to denote the mourning State of the Church under the Oppre≈ø≈øions, and Cruelties of Antichri≈øt, ≈øufficiently de≈øcribed in the following part of that Chapter, and a≈øcribed to the Bea≈øt, v. 7. called v. 8. Sodom, and Egypt, For that gro≈øs Corruption of Manners, and barbarous Tyranny that ≈øhall be found in Antichri≈øt, who under the ≈øame ≈øtile, Ch. 13. 4, 5. hath power given to Him to continue 42 Months: And if for the great Tyranny and Impurities of life the Names of Egypt, and Sodom, ≈øo for the Idolatry that ≈øhould then obtain under the reign of Antichri≈øt, that of Babylon or the great Whore be likewi≈øe given, Rev. 17. 1. 5. So that there is no doubt but a fixt time for the Continuance of this Eclip≈øe in the Church, is ≈øet; A time as for the Impiety, Tyranny, and Idolatry of Antichri≈øt, ≈øo for the Patience, and Faith of the Saints; for they are but the ≈øeveral Epocha's of the≈øe, I have been mentioning.

I do not ≈øuppo≈øe this Impiety, Tyranny, and Idolatry of Antichri≈øt in its heights, the whole time of its duration; For there is as well the gradual Encrea≈øe and Wane, as the the total ob≈øcurity of an Eclip≈øe: Its arriving to its „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ or heighth we ob≈øerv'd before from the 13th of the Revelations, where we likewi≈øe took notice of the mark the Holy Gho≈øt ≈øet upon the number of the Bea≈øt, and offer'd ≈øomething new (but all from the context) in the Explication of his Number of 666: And as to its la≈øt Period and Determination, that is, what we ≈øuppo≈øe to be coucht under the≈øe different reckonings of a Time, Times, and half, or the dividing of a time, of 42 Months, and 1260 days: And if ≈øo, It will then only remain to a≈øcertain, what day: And if ≈øo, It will then only remain to a≈øcertain, what the duration is, of which we are to con≈øtrue the≈øe ≈øeveral Computations; i. e. whether we are to take a Time, Times,
and the dividing or half a time for 3 natural years, and a half: the 42 Months or 1260 days (which is the ≈øame with the former) for ≈øo many natural days, neither more, nor le≈øs: Or, whether we are to take them all, i. e. the days contain'd in 3 years, and a half, or in 42 Months, or expre≈øly 1260 days, for ≈øo many Prophetick days, i. e. For intire years, according to that of Numb. 14. 34. After the number of the days in which ye ≈øearched the Land, even forty days (each day for a year) ≈øhall you bear your Iniquities even forty years: And Ezek. 4. 4, 5, 6. Lye thou al≈øo upon thy left ≈øide, and lay the Iniquity of the Hou≈øe of I≈ørael upon it, according to the number of the days that Thou ≈øhalt lye upon it, Thou ≈øhalt bear their Iniquity; For I have laid upon Thee the years of their Iniquity, according to the number of the days, three hundred and ninety days, ≈øo ≈øhalt thou bear the Iniquity of the Hou≈øe of I≈ørael: And when thou ha≈øt accompli≈øh'd them, lye again on thy right ≈øide, and thou ≈øhall bear the Iniquity of the Hou≈øe of Judah forty days, I have appointed thee each day for a year. 1. Whether to confine the great Events of the Church to ≈øo ≈ømall a ≈øcantling as that of three years and a half, be agreeable to the De≈øcription of the Per≈øon, who here avows him≈øelf to have received this Revelation from God, and to give it to his Servants; I mean that of his being Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the ending, the Lord which is, and which was, and which is to come, the Almighty, Revel. 1. v. 8, & v. 17. of his being the fir≈øt and the la≈øt, he that liveth and was dead, and behold he liveth, Amen; and hath the Keys of Hell, and of Death? For if ≈øo, then Antichri≈øt mu≈øt have then immediately ≈øucceeded, i. e. about the year 314, when Con≈øtantine reo≈øtored Peace to the Church, and freed her from Per≈øecution, and have had his period 1375 years ago. Again, let it be yet con≈øider'd, whether

And now having thus, in what was nece≈ø≈øary to be ob≈øerv'd concerning the ri≈øe and growth of Antichri≈øt, taken notice as of the ≈øeveral periods the Holy Gho≈øt hath ≈øet for either, and the different u≈øe we are in this matter to make of the ≈øeveral Epocha's of the taking of Rome, viz. in 410 and 455, and the divi≈øion of the Empire into ten Kingdoms upon the la≈øt: and thereto added the Te≈øtimony of other Writers, with ≈øome Rea≈øons why a time, times, and half, or the dividing of a time; forty two months, or one thou≈øand two hundred and ≈øixty days, which are all the ≈øame, cannot be taken for natural, but Prophetick days, i. e. for intire years, I might fairly take leave of this point, in which I have been forced to be long, but I hope not tedious: But con≈øidering of how great moment 'tis that every thing ≈øhould be clear, and coherent in ≈øuch a weighty

div.head: CHAP. VII. How this great Eclip≈øe in the Church was to clear up again?
div.p: AND now we are again to follow Daniel in his Prophe≈øy, who tells us, Chap. 7. 27. That the Kingdom, Dominion, and greatne≈øs of the Kingdom under the whole Heaven ≈øhall be given to the People of the Saints of the mo≈øt high, who≈øe Kingdom is an Everla≈øting Kingdom, and all Dominions ≈øhall ≈øerve and obey him: Which the Angel thus expre≈ø≈øes, Revel. 11. 15. The Kingdoms of this World are become the Kingdoms of our Lord, and of his Chri≈øt, and he ≈øhall Reign for ever, and ever: Whereupon the twenty four Elders which ≈øate before God on their Seats, fell upon their Faces, and wor≈øhipped God, ≈øaying, We give thee Thanks, O Lord God Almighty, which art, and wa≈øt, and art to come, becau≈øe thou hast taken to thee thy great Power, and ha≈øt reigned, ver≈ø. 16, 17. Agreeable to what is a≈øcribed to him, Revel. 19. 12. Allelujah, Salvation, and Glory, and Honour, and Power unto the Lord our God; for True and Righteous are his Judgments; for he hath judged the great Whore, which did corrupt the Earth with her Fornication, and hath avenged the Blood of his Servants at her hand: And again, ver≈ø. 6. Allelujah, for the Lord Omnipotent Reigneth: So, that as to the clearing up this Eclip≈øe, the delivering the Church from that Cloud, which ≈øo long was over it, 'twill be by the ruin of Antichri≈øt, and Chri≈øts taking to Him≈øelf the Kingdom his Enemy had ≈øo long u≈øurped.

What manner of Kingdom that ≈øhall be? Whether Temporal or Spiritual, or both? VVhether ≈øo, as that him≈øelf ≈øhall Per≈øonally Reign, or only by his Sub-Admini≈øtrators, is not my bu≈øine≈øs here to determine; though I think too, the di≈øtinction of Reigning Per≈øonally, or by his Sub-admini≈øhrators, (how great Di≈øputes and Controver≈øies ≈øoever it hath bred in the World) is very trifling; for 'tis his per≈øonal Reign, what
he now hath, it is as He is Je≈øus, who was Crucified, that He is made both Lord, and Chri≈øt, Acts 2. 36.
