p.hi: AND I heard a great Voice out of the Temple, ≈øaying to the ≈øeven Angels, Go your ways, and pour out the Vials of the Wrath of God upon the Earth.

div.p: The Voice out of the Temple ≈øpeaks it to be from God, and to re≈øpect the Affairs of the Church; and its being ≈øaid to be a great Voice, ≈øhews the Terrour it brings with it, and the certain Succe≈øs, the things it ≈øpeaks are to have, and that 'tis a Voice that will be heard.

The Angels being bid to go their ways, and pour out the Vials, makes it evident that it is not the Church in its Purity, (the Temple from whence this Voice comes,) that is to be the Subject of the≈øe Plagues.

The Angels not going on this Errand till bid, demon≈øtrates as their Obedience to the Commands of their great Ma≈øter, ≈øo their unwillingne≈øs to be the Executioners of Vengeance, till expre≈øly ≈øent.
Their being called Vials, is in allu≈øion to Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øo called, to fignifie the definite mea≈øure of Divine Judgments, and the manner in which they are poured out.

Their being Vials of the Wrath of God, ≈øhews them to be the Effects of his Ju≈øtice on impenitent Sinners, that Justice of his, which he executes not till provoked to it, but ≈øuch, as when executed, there's no avoiding.

The Vials full of the Wrath of God being given unto them by one of the four Bea≈øts, ch. 15. ver. 7. (for this too is here to be taken in) di≈øcovers the high regard God hath to his Mini≈øters, and the Prayers of his People (for of tho≈øe may be under≈øtood the four Bea≈øts, ch. 4. 6, 7, 8.) it being the ≈øame Bea≈øt, that gives the Seven Vials unto the ≈øeven Angels, which had Golden Vials full of Odours, which are Prayers of Saints; for of each of them is this affirmed, ch. 5. 8.

By Earth in this Book I take generally to be ≈øignified, what is oppo≈øite to Heaven, ≈øo that if Heaven ≈øignifie the Church, or the Eccle≈øia≈øtical State, Earth will ≈øignifie what is Secular, and properly of this World, i. e. The Earthly, and Temporal Power, and its Subjects, as the≈øe ≈øtand in oppo≈øition to the other: But ≈øomething more ≈øeems to be meant by Earth in this Ver≈øe, viz. as 'tis taken for every thing in this Lower, Material World, and ≈øo not only the gro≈ø≈øer part of this great Sy≈øtem of Nature, which we call Earth in di≈øtinction from the other parts of it, but the Sea, Rivers, Sun it ≈øelf, with the Circumambient Air, are by a Synecdoche of this more eminent part taken for the whole, hereby to be under≈øtood: This I cannot but ob≈øerve here, becau≈øe the Seven Vials, which are afterwards ≈øaid to be pour'd out on the≈øe ≈øeveral parts of the Univer≈øe, (as things are here metaphorically thereby ≈øignified) are all ≈øaid here to be poured out upon the Earth.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the fir≈øt VIAL.
div.p: AND the fir≈øt (Angel) went and poured out his Vial upon the Earth, and there fell a noi≈øom, and grievous Sore upon the Men which had the mark of the Bea≈øt, and upon them which wor≈øhipped his Image. Revel. 16. 2.

By Earth here, as is ju≈øt now ob≈øerved, is ≈øignified what is oppo≈øite to Heaven, ≈øo that if Heaven ≈øignifies the Church, or Eccle≈øie≈øtical State, Earth will ≈øignifie what is Secular, and Properly of this World; and if ≈øo, it will intimate this Vial to concern in the fir≈øt place the whole Roman Empire, the Secular, Earthly, and Temporal Power there in Being; but ≈øo that (as it follows) it ≈øhall in particular fall on tho≈øe of its Subjects, which had the mark of the Bea≈øt, and which wor≈øhipped his Image. And that requires, that we con≈øider here, 1. what is meant by the Bea≈øt? 2. What it is we are to under≈øtand by his Mark? 3. What by his Image? And

1. What is meant by the Bea≈øt?
Now 'tis evident that by the Bea≈øt is to be under≈øtood that Power, which ro≈øe up in the place of what was Imperial: For ≈øo 'tis prophe≈øied 2 The≈ø≈ø. 2. 7, 8. And ≈øo it was repre≈øented to St. John in his Vi≈øion, Revel. 13. 11. And I beheld another Bea≈øt coming up out of the Earth; another in di≈øtinction from what was before, but a Bea≈øt ≈øtill, to ≈øhew that 'tis the ≈øame Power, that is ≈øtill continued, though with re≈øpect to him, who exerci≈øes it, it is but „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ the Image of the former; for ≈øo he who was to come up in his place, viz. the Pope, is: The name of Emperor indeed he takes not upon him, but he exerci≈øes all the Power of the fir≈øt Bea≈øt before him, ver. 12. i. e. So overrules and controuls the Secular Power, as to make it ≈øub≈øervient to what he hath po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of, i. e. To what is ≈øpiritual: He exerci≈øes all his Power before him,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . As 'tis in his Pre≈øence under the ≈øhew, and covert of his Authority he doth it: As he permits him to have the name of doing that, wherein he is only his Tool to excute ≈øuch Sentences, as he (the Pope) ≈øhall fir≈øt decree; for there's the whole juggle of delivering up Offenders to the Secular Power, which is to proceed again≈øt them without any farther Tryal, or Cognizance of the cau≈øe, for which they are thus remitted to the Civil Magistrate.

And that it is added, He cau≈øeth the Earth, and them that dwell therein to wor≈øhip the fir≈øt Bea≈øt, who≈øe deadly Wound was healed; this mu≈øt be under≈øtood by con≈øidering what his deadly Wound was, Which in all probability was the blow he received in having Pagani≈øm and Idolatry (for to that Wor≈øhipping will mo≈øt properly relate) beaten down; but not without including al≈øo that Supream Power, from whence he was ca≈øt down at the di≈ø≈øolution of the We≈øtern Empire: Indeed both, i. e. The Imperial Power, and Idolatry under it, went together, (excepting for the ≈øhort breathing time Chri≈øtianity had under Con≈øtantine, and the re≈øtoring either or both in their Image, mu≈øt denote, as the ≈øhew of Power to which the Bea≈øt again revived after that deadly Blow received by the Goths, Hunns, and Vandals, ≈øo that ≈øhew of Idolatry, i. e. That other ≈øort of Idolatry, which under degenerated Chri≈øtianity ≈øucceeded into the place of what was Pagan, or meerly Heatheni≈øh; the rea≈øon in all likelihood why the outward Court (whether to be
under≈øtood of the Territories of Antichri≈øt, or the outward ≈øhew of Religion, as it ≈øhould all along be profe≈ø≈øed by degenerate Chri≈øtians) is ≈øaid to be given to the Gentiles, Revel. 11. 2. And the Holy City, (i. e. true Religion in its Purity) to be trodden under foot forty two Months.

So then it is evident, what we are to under≈øtand by the Bea≈øt? i. e. the Supream Power, as 'tis now u≈øurped by the Pope, though in the ≈øhew of it given to him, who wears the name of Emperor, rai≈øed to that Stile and Power by the Pope (for ≈øo Carolus Magnus, and his Succe≈ø≈øors were) and upheld therein in order to that Power, which he and his followers have from that time exerci≈øed before him. The next thing to be here con≈øidered, is,
2. What we are to under≈øtand by his Mark?

And that, I que≈øtion not, is well applied to that Profe≈ø≈øion of Errors, and wicked Practices the Pope requires from his followers: The former very properly ≈øaid to be the mark in the Forehead, as the latter is, in the Hand. And,

3. As to his Image, we have already touched at that, under the fir≈øt of the≈øe Enquiries, as it is the Image, whether of Power or Idolatry aboli≈øhed with the Roman Empire, properly ≈øo called, but re≈øtored, as we have above interpreted it, under the Papacy; for as to both the≈øe „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
his Image relates and the Controver≈øie then moved in the Church about „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Images, and their wor≈øhip, (which is well known to have been the great. Debate about the time, that a new Emperor was ≈øet up in the We≈øt,) ≈øeems to give us particular light in this matter.

The Controver≈øie, as is already ob≈øerved, began about the Year 725, and la≈øted till about 840, and gives the faire≈øt Ri≈øe imaginable for our Conjecture of what was the Bu≈øine≈øs of the fir≈øt Vial, viz. the Judgment that overtook this great Corruption of the Church, in the Irruptions of the Saracens, the matter more ≈øtrictly now to be enquired into.

And for this, methinks we have a very proper Key in what the Holy Gho≈øt a≈ø≈øigns for the Subject of this Plague, as it was to be upon the Men which had the Mark of the Bea≈øt, and wor≈øhipped his Image; which if to be under≈øtood of tho≈øe who had given up them≈øelves to that Idolatry, or Image-wor≈øhip
which then obtained, will very directly lead us to that Judgment, which in that Age was poured out upon ≈øuch: And is it not evident the Irruptions of the Saracens were ≈øo?

For was it not agreeable to the Principles of their pretended Prophet Mahomet, (one of which was to de≈øtroy Idols, as Elmachinus in his Hi≈øtorta Saracenica, p. 3. informs us „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
destruxit
que Idolorum Cultum) to make War upon the Wor≈øhippers of Images?

And was it not at this time they made their great inroads upon them? And 'tis very remarkable, (but of that only by the by) that the name of Reproach the≈øe Imagemongers ca≈øt upon Leo Iconomachus, was „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ≈øo he is Nicknamed Theophan. Chronogr. p. 339. as one that was of the ≈øame Opinion with the Saracens, and as ≈øuch they likewi≈øe endeavour'd to blot others of the Iconocla≈øts.

And certainly, to come to our purpo≈øe, and the words in which the Holy Gho≈øt hath been pleas'd to expre≈øs this Vial, nothing can more de≈øervedly be term'd a grievous and noi≈øome Sore, than that was:

For how was it in it ≈øelf, with re≈øpect to that Corruption it brought with it into the Church, the mo≈øt putrifying, infectious, abominable ≈øore, that ever broke out on any body? How with re≈øpect to the Applications that were made to this ≈øpreading Lepro≈øie, I mean the Judgments, which ≈øo manife≈øtly followed it, the mo≈øt painful, fretting wound that men could receive? „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , 'twas wickedne≈øs, and Impiety in the highe≈øt was the wound, and Vengeance agreeable to ≈øuch Impiety and Wickedne≈øs, was the proper attendant thereof.

The Sore, noi≈øome Di≈øea≈øe or Infection, began (as is already ob≈øerv'd) with the fir≈øt ri≈øing up of the Bea≈øt, and ≈øeems to have been confirm'd in the publick enacting of Idolatry (≈øo I call it) in the ≈øeventh general, or ≈øecond Council of Nice, wherein Wor≈øhip and Adoration was Decreed to belong to Images.

And as for the wound and vengeance agreeable to ≈øuch Impiety, i. e. the Vial poured out for it, that may very well be under≈øtood of the forementioned Irruptions of the Saracens, e≈øpecially what happen'd between the years 820 and 830; for 'twas then they had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Spain, Calabria, Apulia, and mo≈øt part of Italy, Petav. Ration. Tempor. part 1. l. 8. p. 389.
and could not be driven thence till about the year 980; i. e. 150 years after the time when the Tails of the≈øe Scorpions (as they are de≈øcribed in the 5th Trumpet, Revel. 9. 10.) did ≈øo thorowly ≈øting them, as 'tis ≈øaid in the Text, for five months which makes up in Prophetick days the ≈øaid 150 years.

Now this I doubt not, but may be very well a≈ø≈øign'd, as the bu≈øine≈øs of the fir≈øt Vial, the pouring of it out upon the Earth, ≈øuppo≈øing the We≈øtern Empire, in the ≈øen≈øe we gave of Earth, as applied in this Book to ≈øignifie the Secular, or Earthly Power, to be fir≈øt re≈øtored, before it could be the Subject of the ≈øaid Vial; as al≈øo the Subjects of it to have received the Mark of the Bea≈øt, and to have wor≈øhipped his Image, which, with re≈øpect to the fir≈øt could not be be≈øore the year 800 (for it was then the Empire was re≈øtored) with re≈øpect to the ≈øecond, not well before the aforementioned ≈øecond Council of Nice; For however Image-Wor≈øhip had before gained too great Footing, and the Mark began to be ≈øet, yet it could not be well ≈øaid to be ≈øettled till then; the Con≈øequence whereof mu≈øt be this, that there, or from thence forward we are to look for the pouring out the fir≈øt Vial; and nothing, if con≈øidered, as in the Rea≈øon that moved the Saracens to invade them, ≈øo in the Mi≈øchiefs they were the Authors of, can more naturally an≈øwer the Metaphon of a noi≈øom and grievous Sore. And therefore till any thing el≈øe be offered that may better explain this, I ≈øhall not doubt to re≈øt herein for the Explication of the fir≈øt Vial.

Only I do not ≈øo re≈øtrain this to the We≈øtern Empire, as not to ≈øee the ≈øame Vial, though in a le≈øs Degree, poured on ≈øome parts of the Ea≈øtern Empire; but that I take rather to be a Merciful Warning to them, who ≈øhould afterwards ≈øuffer more deeply under their Violence, when the the three Woes foretold, Revel. 8. 13. were to take place.

p.hi: AND the ≈øecond Angel poured out his Vial upon the Sea, and it became as the Blood of a dead Man, and every living Soul died in the Sea.

div.p: The Sea is the great Confluence of Waters, and Waters, we know, the Angel interpreting it to St. John, Rev. 17. 15. ≈øignifie Peoples, Multitudes, Nations, and Tongues; which being ≈øaid to become as the Blood of a dead Man, and every Soul dying in it, may import very great Saughters, and univer≈øal Blood≈øhed among tho≈øe, who are to be the Subjects of this Vial.

Now what can better interpret this, than the Cru≈øado's, or Holy Wars, wherein ≈øo much Blood was ≈øpilt? And to this the Series of Hi≈øtory naturally leads us; for if in the pouring out of the former Vial, the Saracens invade the We≈øtern Empire, and tho≈øe therein (for 'tis ob≈øervable, indeed it could not be otherwi≈øe, it being commanded them, that they ≈øhould not hurt any but only tho≈øe who have not the Seal of God in their Foreheads, Rev. 9. 4. That in all the Inva≈øions and Wars the Saracens or Turks have made, that they have never bent their Force again≈øt tho≈øe who di≈øclaimed the Idolatries of Antichri≈øt, tho≈øe they were, again≈øt whom, neither then nor in later times they ≈øeem to have had their Commi≈ø≈øion) that had the mark of the Bea≈øt, and wor≈øhipped his Image, 'tis but in a way of Retaliation that tho≈øe who had the Mark of the Bea≈øt, and wor≈øhipped his Image, ≈øhould carry back the War into the Territories of the Saracens, to revenge their former Incur≈øions, to recover Pale≈øtine, with Jeru≈øalem, and the Temple of the Sepulcher out of the hands of the Infidels.

Accordingly Urban the Second in pur≈øuit of what he knew to have been often attempted by his Predece≈ø≈øor, Gregory the Seventh, (but wherein he was hindred by the Factions
of Schi≈ømaticks, and ≈øeveral Wars, (≈øo Baronius tells us Anno 1090,) and at the in≈øtance of Alexius the Emperor of Con≈øtantinople, who≈øe Letters had been lately read in the Council of Placentia, declares the fir≈øt Expedition in the Council of Claremont called chiefly for this work; the ≈øecond Canon whereof was this, Quicunque pro≈øol√¢ devotione, non pro, Honoris vel lucri adeptione, ad liberandam Eccle≈øiam Dei Jeru≈øalem profectus fuerit, iter illud pro omni poenitenti√¢ reputetur: Who≈øoever out of meer Devotion, and not for the getting of Honour, or Gain, ≈øhall go to Jeru≈øalem to deliver the Church of God, let that Journey be accounted in the ≈øtead of all Repentance whatever; and for the farther encouragement of tho≈øe who ≈øhould undertake the Expedition, in one of the Speeches he makes on this occa≈øion, as Malmsburien≈øis relates it, 'tis decreed by him, omnia bona eorum, qui Hiero≈øolymas pergunt, ≈øemper & ubique e≈ø≈øe ≈øalva in pace, & treuga, quou≈øque redierint: That all the Goods of tho≈øe who go to Jeru≈øalem ≈øhould always and every where be ≈øafe, in Peace and Truce, till they ≈øhall return.

And now what ha≈øtening is there to this Holy War, in which they ≈øhould thus merit the Pardon of all their Sins, and be ≈øecure that all their Goods and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions ≈øhould be kept in ≈øafety for them? ≈øuch (≈øaith Baronius) were the Crouds of tho≈øe who li≈øted their Names, that 'twas nece≈ø≈øary to dehort them from going, who≈øe Age and Health were not fit for military Service: Very great indeed were their numbers; Malmsburien≈øis thinks that if the ≈øeveral Armies had been entred in one Mu≈øter-Roll, they would have made ≈øixty hundred thou≈øand: He that ≈øhall con≈øider this, with the great Recruits that were afterwards made in the continuance of tho≈øe Wars, and the ≈ømall number of tho≈øe who ever returned to give an account of their great Exploits there, will not at all wonder that the Holy-Gho≈øt ≈øhould plea≈øe to expre≈øs it by a Sea of Blood.

Indeed Urban, as well as his Predece≈ø≈øor Gregory the ≈øeventh, (who fir≈øt de≈øigned the Expedition, though he could never bring it to any effect) and tho≈øe of his Succe≈ø≈øors, who were herein concerned, were well advi≈øed in the Policy of the De≈øign: For what could be more for the advantage of that exorbitant Power at which they aimed, than to give this
diver≈øion to tho≈øe neighbouring Princes, which they had rea≈øon to fear would ≈øtand in their way? Though neither could they do that ≈øo effectually, as not at the ≈øame to be nece≈ø≈øitated to Wars at Home: what with other Antipopes (as they were ≈øet up ≈øometimes by the Emperor, ≈øometimes be Faction among them≈øelves, ≈øometimes by other Princes) what with the Emperor, and tho≈øe other Princes which abetted the Faction, or for other rea≈øons were at Enmity with the Pope, nothing but Blood was the effect of this Vial; Blood, like that of a dead Man, and every living Soul died in the Sea: i. e. Not every individual Per≈øon but ≈øome of all ≈øorts, and in all places, throughout the whole Sea, in the Sen≈øe we have above given of it, peri≈øhed in the≈øe Slaughters; ≈øo univer≈øal as well as fatal was this Plague to tho≈øe who had the mark of the Bea≈øt, and wor≈øhipped his Image.

And herein we place the Bu≈øine≈øs of the ≈øecond Vial, in di≈øtinction from what the third holds forth to us, which being to be poured out upon the Rivers and Fountains of Waters, as the other was upon the Sea, ≈øeems to denote that Vial to be of the ≈øame nature with the former, but more restrained as to its extent, and the quality of tho≈øe, who are to be the Subjects of it.

I know very well there were other very ≈øignal Events, which fell out about tho≈øe times, which will very well de≈øerve our con≈øideration in this matter, as being very capable of the Character, that is here given to the fir≈øt Vial, viz. of a noi≈øome and grievous ≈øore upon the men which had the mark of the Bea≈øt, and which Wor≈øhipp'd his Image; ≈øuch were what happen'd to them from the Berengarians and Walden≈øes, or Albigen≈øes, tho≈øe great Witne≈ø≈øes (I was almo≈øt going to ≈øay the two Witne≈ø≈øes) which ≈øo long Prophe≈øied in Sackcloath, i. e. under the Per≈øecutions of the Romi≈øh Church; by the former of the≈øe, Wernerus Carthu≈øianus, Fa≈øc. Temp. aetat. 6. circa Annu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Chri≈øti 1064; affirms the Romi≈øh Church to have been for a long time ≈øufficiently afflicted: And Lancelot de Voy≈øin Poplinerius, Hi≈øt. Franc. l. 1. edit. 1581. f. 7. affirms her never to have been more fiercely re≈øisted than by the latter, i. e.
a Walden≈øibus & eorum in Aquitani√¢ ac vicina regione ≈øucce≈ø≈øoribus, qui ab Albio, Albien≈øium in Septimani√¢ urbe primari√¢, Albigen≈øes dicti ≈øunt. Hi invitis Principibus Chri≈øtians omnibus, circa annum 1100. &
temporibus ≈øub≈øequentibus, doctrinam ≈øuam, ab e√¢ quam hodie Protestantes amplectuntur, parum differentem, non per Galliam ≈øolum totam, ≈øed etiam per omnes pene Europae oras di≈ø≈øeminarunt: Nam Galli, Hi≈øpani, Angli, Scoti, Itali, Germani, Bohemi, Saxones, Poloni, Lithuani & Gentes aliae eam ad hunc diem pertinaciter defenderunt; than by the Walden≈øes and their Succe≈ø≈øors, in Aquitain and the neighbouring Country, who from Albium, the chief City of the Albien≈øes in Septimani√¢, are called Albigen≈øes. The≈øe again≈øt the will of all Chri≈øtian Princes, about the year 1100. and in the following times, ≈øpread their Doctrine (very little differing from what the Prote≈øtants at this day embrace) not only throughout all France, but al≈øo almo≈øt throughout all the Coa≈øts of Europe. For the French, the Spaniards, the Engli≈øh, the Scots, the Italians, the Germans, the Bohemians, the Saxons, the Polonians, the Lithuanians, and other Nations, have pertinaciou≈øly defended it to this day. Reinerius the Inqui≈øitor (in his Book cont. Haeret. c. 4. p. 54. Edit. Ingol≈øtad. An. 1613) goes farther, inter omnes ≈øectas quae adhuc ≈øunt vel fuerunt, non e≈øt pernicio≈øior Eccle≈øiae, quam Leoni≈øtarum, & hoc tribus de cau≈øis; prima e≈øt, quia e≈øt diuturnior, aliqui enim dicunt, quod duraverit a tempore Silve≈øtri, aliqui a tempore Apo≈øtolorum; ≈øecunda, quia e≈øt generalior, fere enim nulla e≈øt terra, in qu√¢ haec ≈øecta non ≈øit; Tertia, &c. among≈øt all the Sects which yet are, or have been, none is more pernicious to the Church, than that of the Leoni≈øts (i. e. Pauperes de Lugduno) and this for three Rea≈øons, the fir≈øt is, becau≈øe it is more la≈øting than any other, for ≈øome ≈øay that it hath continued from the time of Sylve≈øter, ≈øome from the time of the Apo≈øtles; the ≈øecond, becau≈øe 'tis more general, for there is almo≈øt no Country, in which this Sect is not; the third, &c.

And 'tis ob≈øervable, that Alexander the Third, in the Canon publi≈øh'd again≈øt them, In Synodo Turonen≈øi, Anno 1163. gives it a Name not altogether unlike to this of a ≈øore and grievous wound, affirming it to ≈øpread more Cancri, as a Canker, &c. and particularly forbids to buy and ≈øell, Revel. 13. 17.

In the Year 1170, he fends one of the Cardinals to make War upon them, and indeed what is there that could be attempted, that the Romani≈øts have not done to de≈øtroy them, but with no better ≈øucce≈øs than to encrea≈øe them by this oppo≈øition?
So noi≈øom and grievous, ≈øo pain≈øul and fretting hath the Sore ≈øtill been, which by the≈øe fell upon the Men which had the Mark of the Bea≈øt, and which wor≈øhipped his Image.

But then, whether this may be reckoned one of the particular Vials I am ≈øomething doubtful, it being a Sore that ≈øeemed rather to run through them all, and what either the Berengarians, or the Walden≈øes, or Albingen≈øes (or whatever other name is given them) witne≈ø≈øed again≈øt the growing Corruptions of the Romi≈øh Chnrch, being rather to point out her Sins, for which the Vials were poured out: But if a Particular Vial it be allowed to be, it mu≈øt come in in the ≈øecond place, and then the Sea (upon which it is ≈øaid to be poured) becomming as the Blood of a Dead Man, and every living Soul dying in it, wil ≈øignifie that ≈øtagnation, if I may ≈øo expre≈øs it, there was in all its Veins, that mortified State into which the whole Church of Rome was every where brought, that ≈øtop ≈øhe received in all her Vital Actions, i. e. In that Pride, Luxury, and Idolatry which were grown predominant, but wherein ≈øhe could never receive a more deadly Blow, then what was given her by the Berengarians, and Walden≈øes. But this, how fairly ≈øoever offer'd, for the rea≈øon above toucht at, I choo≈øe to wave, and ≈øo proceed to the third Vial as before pointed out.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the third VIAL, Revel. 16 4.

p.hi: AND the third Angel poured out his Vial upon the Rivers, and Fountains of Waters, and they became blood.

div.p: The former Vial is poured out upon the Sea, and is ≈øaid to become blood: Here 'tis on the Rivers, and Fountains of Waters, and tho≈øe likewi≈øe ≈øaid to become blood.

And if the Sea and Waters in the Prophetick ≈øtile ≈øignifie Peoples, and Multitudes, and Nations, and Tongues, as we ob≈øerv'd from Revel. 17. 15. Con≈øequently, Rivers will ≈øignifie but ≈øome part of the≈øe, as Rivers make but part of that confluence of Waters, which meet alother in the Sea. And if Rivers be but part of the Sea, or of the Waters in that larger extent, i. e. be but ≈øome of tho≈øe many Peoples, Multitudes, or Nations, or Tongues, on whom the former Vial was poured, Fountains of Waters will in all likelihood be the Princes of tho≈øe Peoples, Multitudes, Nations, and Tongues, tho≈øe being as the Head, or Spring to the others, who as to the Publick and its Affairs, derive their fir≈øt Ri≈øe and Motion in all their actings from them: They are Princes which give life to their Subjects, direct the Channel and Cour≈øe they are to run in.

Now what can better ≈øuit this Prediction, than what happen'd in the later Cru≈øadoes, or Expeditions to the Holy Land, which were not ≈øo general as the fir≈øt, and wherein only ≈øome particular Princes were concern'd?
The Effu≈øion of blood, though great, yet 'twas but on the Rivers, and Fountains of Waters, 'twas not that Sea of blood, which in the fir≈øt Cru≈øadoes overflowed all Chri≈øtendom.

But there's another circum≈øtance that mu≈øt not be pa≈øt by, and that is, As this Vial is ≈øaid to be poured out particularly on the Fountains of Waters, by which, as is above offered, are to be under≈øtood Princes; and how it affected them, will not be doubted, if be≈øides the lo≈øs they ≈øu≈øtain'd in the ≈ølaughter of their Subjects, we ≈øhall con≈øider what in the
time of the Cru≈øadoes they ≈øuffer'd too in their Soveraignty.

For was it not then, that the Bi≈øhops of Rome taking the advantage of their ab≈øence, whil≈øt in their Expeditions to the Holy Land, contrary to what had been decreed by Urban (viz. That all the Goods of tho≈øe, who go to Jeru≈øalem, ≈øhould always, and every where be ≈øafe in Peace and Truce, till they ≈øhould return) ≈øo infinitely encrea≈øed his own Power, and le≈ø≈øen'd theirs, ab≈øolutely po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing him≈øelf of ≈øome of their Kingdoms, and making others hold theirs as Feudatory from him? And this but agreeable to what Urban had Decreed in the Council of Claremont, wherein he likewi≈øe Publi≈øh'd the fir≈øt of the≈øe Expeditions, viz.
Eccle≈øiam ab omni ≈øervitute Regum liberam, that the Church was free from all ≈øervice to Kings, ac proinde Inve≈øtituram √† clericis recipiendam non e≈ø≈øe, and from thence that no inve≈øtiture was to be received from them by the Clergy.
From whence it appears what it was, they were then aiming at, and how far they effected it, this Vial doth ≈øufficiently declare.

And this but as a proper Puni≈øhment for their Sins; for if Kings and Princes be ≈øo negligent of his Honour, who ≈øet them on their Thrones, as to fall down before Stocks and Stones, and wor≈øhip whatever Idols Antichri≈øt ≈øhall ≈øet up; how can they expect, but that God ≈øhould give them up to the Vanities to which they had pro≈øtituted them≈øelves, as 'tis P≈øal. 106. 36. that their Idols they have ≈øerved, ≈øhould be their ≈ønare?

As how ≈øhould they, who are Gods Vicegerents, his Vicars on Earth, (There was a time, when the Popes them≈øelves could give them that Stile) and yet ≈øo far forget him, who≈øe ≈øub≈øtitutes they are, as to change the Glory of the uncorruptible God, into an Image made like corruptible man, and to Birds, and fourfooted Bea≈øts, and creeping things, Rom. 1. 23. or any other Image, hope that he ≈øhould maintain their Rights, who ≈øo highly invade his Prerogative?

This being con≈øider'd as the Rea≈øon of the thing, and the event an≈øwering the ob≈øervation, I ≈øhall only add for the di≈øtingui≈øhing tho≈øe two Plagues or Vials from each other, the time which I think may very well be a≈øcribed to either; and
to the fir≈øt I a≈ø≈øign that interval of time, which comes in between the year 1095. (when the fir≈øt Expedition to the Holy Land was publi≈øh'd by Urban the Second) and 1196, the year when Cele≈øtine the Third ≈øent his Legate into Germany to procure a new Expedition of the Princes to Syria: To the ≈øecond I a≈ø≈øign the time that from thence ≈øucceeded, till the Saracens recover'd Syria from them, which was about the year 1291.

And here I cannot tell whether we may not apply what we read, Revel. 8. 10, 11. in the time of the ≈øounding of the third Trumpet, viz. of a great Star falling from Heaven, burning as it were a Lamp, and falling upon the third part of the Rivers, and upon the Fountains of Waters: And the name by which the Star is called, is Wormwood; and the third part of the Waters became Wormwood, and many men dyed of the Waters, becau≈øe they were made bitter.

For what ≈øo proper to ≈øignifie the grand Apo≈øta≈øie of Antichri≈øt, as the falling of a great Star from Heaven? A Star, in the interpretation of Chri≈øt him≈øelf, Revel. 1. 20. being to be under≈øtood of an Angel, or Bi≈øhop of the Church, (as Bi≈øhops were called in the fir≈øt times of the Go≈øpel, and therefore ≈øo repre≈øented to St. John.) For is it not from the Purity of the Go≈øpel, the Admini≈øtration whereof is ≈øo often called Heaven in the New-Te≈øtament, this great Light, the fir≈øt Star in the Firmament falls? but ≈øo falls too, that as to his Temporal Eminence, he becomes more illu≈øtrious, gaining that in ≈øecular Intere≈øt, which he lo≈øes in what is Spiritual? therefore ≈øaid to burn as it were a Lamp, which ≈øpeaks outward Splendor, but ≈øo that 'tis burning ≈øtill, full of danger and terror to tho≈øe who are too forward to be meddling with it. And if its name is called Wormwood. what ≈øo fully an≈øwers that Metaphor, as the Wrongs and Inju≈øtice which were then done? (For ≈øo the Antithe≈øis is Amos 5. 7. Between Judgment and Wormwood.)

Never indeed were ≈øuch bitter times, whether for the Rancour of Mens Minds, the Hatred between the Popes, and Soveraign Princes, or for the Injuries and Exactions they oppre≈ø≈øed them and their Subjects, i. e. Both the Rivers and Fountains of Waters with.

And the third part of the Waters becoming Wormwood, may ≈øignifie the extent of the≈øe ∆≤≈øurpations, either with reference
to the ab≈øolute Va≈ø≈øallage of tho≈øe, he thus en≈ølaved in general out of all Peoples, Multitudes, Nations and Tongues; or be more particularly under≈øtood of tho≈øe three Kingdoms of the ten which gave their Power to the Bea≈øt, (and three is the neare≈øt number whereby to take a third part of Ten,) which he ≈øo entirely u≈øurped to him≈øelf, with his ≈øhutting the Gates of Rome by a perpetual Edict, that ne in po≈øterum quis aut Rex aut Princeps Magi≈øtratum ip≈øum petere aut obire auderet, that for the future, none, whether King, or Prince, ≈øhould dare to ≈øeek for, or exerci≈øe Magi≈øtracy there. It was the Decrce of Nicolaus the 3d. Qui Senatoriam Urbis Romanae dignitatem, quam Clemens quartus Regi Carolo dederat, ad ≈øe tran≈øtulit, Anno 1278. Who transferred to him≈øelf the Senatorian Dignity of the City of Rome, which Clemens the fourth had given to King Charles.

But there is ≈øtill one thing more to be taken notice of, it is what we have in the clo≈øe of this Vial, ver. 5, 6, 7. And I heard the Angel of the Waters ≈øay, Thou art Righteous, O Lord, which art, and wa≈øt, and wa≈øt, and ≈øhalt be, becau≈øe thou ha≈øt Judged thus. For they have ≈øhed the Blood of Saints and Prophets, and thou ha≈øt given them Blood to drink; for they are worthy. And I heard another out of the Altar ≈øay, Even ≈øo Lord God Almighty, true and righteous are thy Judgments; which three Ver≈øes I take to be a reflection on the three preceeding Vials, and not only to belong to the la≈øt of them: Indeed it ≈øeems to be like the an≈øwer to the Cry of the Souls under the Altar, under the fifth Seal, ch. 6. 9, 10. that were ≈ølain for the word of God, and for the Te≈øtimony they held, who cryed with a loud Voice, ≈øaying, How long O Lord, Holy and true, do≈øt thou not Judge, and avenge our Blood on them that dwell on the Earth? For it is out of the Altar, another Angel ≈øays, confirming the applau≈øe the former had given to the divine Ju≈øtice; even ≈øo Lord God Almighty, true and righteous are thy Judgments.

To the Souls under the Altar, in the ≈øixth Chapter, it was ≈øaid, that they ≈øhould rest yet for a little Sea≈øon, until their Fellow-Servants al≈øo and their Brethren, which ≈øhould be killed as they were, ≈øhould be fulfilled; and here the Judgments and Vengeance tho≈øe concerned in the Via≈øs, may be lookt upon to have called for, fall on their Murtherers; expre≈øt by a grievous and noi≈øom Sore falling
upon the Men which had the Mark of the Bea≈øt, and upon them which wor≈øhipped his Image, by the irruptions of the Saracens in the fir≈øt Vial.

By the Seas becoming Blood, in the va≈øt effu≈øion of it, whereof the People, Multitudes, Nations, and Tongues were made the Subjects in the expedition to the Holy Land, under the ≈øecond Vial: And then

By the Rivers, and Fountains of Waters becoming likewi≈øe Blood, in what the Princes and People jointly felt, (though not ≈øo generally as under the former) under the following Cru≈øade, with the particular reference to the Conte≈øt (for ≈øo 'tis too in the third and fourth Trumpet which carry ≈øomething paralled to what we here ob≈øerve) which not only in the third but in all the three first Vials there was between the Bi≈øhop of Rome, and Soveraign Priuces for the Supremacy.

All which being heavy Judgments on the Roman Empire, whether in the whole, or in its Parts, are animadverted on, as the re≈øult of that Cruelty, they in any Capacity had exerci≈øed on the Saints; before indeed by the Irrnptions of the Goths and Vandals and Hunns, he that had led into Captivity was led into Captivity, Rome taken, and the Calamities, which attend a Captive ≈øtate, thereon en≈øuing; here he is followed with farther Vengeance, and the reflection the Holy Gho≈øt makes thereon, is to comfort the Saints, who≈øe Patience and Faith is ≈øaid to be here, ch. 10. 10. and to a≈ø≈øure them that their Blood is not ≈øo ≈øpilt on the Ground, but that the Cry ef it ≈øhall be heard in its ju≈øt time again≈øt the enraged and bloody Per≈øecutor.

This was the ≈øtate of the Empire, both in its Civil, and Eccle≈øia≈øtical Capacity under the three fir≈øt Vials, and the rea≈øon of it as before is mentioned, was; For they have ≈øhed the Blood of Saints and Prophets, and thou ha≈øt given them Blood to drink, for they are worthy.

But then it will be ≈øaid, what is this to Antichri≈øt? To the Bea≈øt? For all this is but to aggrandize him; to ≈øet him upon the Throne, and make the Princes of the World to ≈øubmit their Scepters to his Pa≈øtoral Staff.

But be it ≈øo: For thus he is got into the Chair; yet if it be nothing to the Bea≈øt, if all be ≈øo much for his temporal Grandeur, however, certainly they were Plagues
upon the Men who had the Mark of the Bea≈øt, and upon them which wor≈øhipped his Image, chap. 16. 2. Plagues too upon the Bea≈øt him≈øelf, whil≈øt he is permitted to go on from one Degree of Wickedne≈øs to another; it is not his pro≈øpering in his Mi≈øchief, makes it the le≈ø≈øer, but the greater Judgement, as it is the certain tcken of utter ruin that ≈øhall attend him, when, as 'tis ≈øaid of the Ammonites, Gen. 15. 16. His Iniquity ≈øhall be full.

Only it will be demanded, becau≈øe I here make the Reflection on the 5, 6, and 7th ver≈øes of the 16th Chapter, to be as it were a ≈øecond an≈øwer to the Cry of the Souls under the Altar, to whom it was ≈øaid, that they ≈øhould re≈øt for a little Sea≈øon, until their Fellow-≈øervants al≈øo, and their Brethren that ≈øhould be killed as they were, ≈øhould be fulfilled, it will I ≈øay, be demanded,
1. Who of their Fellow-Servants and Brethren had been killed in that Sea≈øon? Or,
2. Whether they were then fulfilled?

As to the fir≈øt, Who of their Fellow-Servants, and Brethren had been killed in that Sea≈øon? 'Tis manife≈øt, it was in that Sea≈øon the Albigen≈øes and Walden≈øes were ≈øo barbarou≈øly Murthered; for it was then Innocent the 3d publi≈øhed the taking up of the Cro≈øs again≈øt them about the year 1211. In the managing whereof, Simon Montford was General, and above a hundred thou≈øand of them then ≈ølain; but in the whole Pro≈øecution of the War, infinite numbers are ≈øaid to peri≈øh; ≈øuch was the ≈ølaughter of them, that in France alone (unhappy France to have been ≈øo early, and ≈øo long the ≈øcene of ≈øo great Barbarity! But happy France too! which hath brought forth ≈øo many faithful Witne≈ø≈øes, who cannot be ≈øo overcome, and killed, but that they are to revive, their Cau≈øe, and Intere≈øt at lea≈øt to be ≈øo ≈øet up, as to ≈øtrike Fear, Terror, and Amazement to all that make War again≈øt them! Revel. 11. 7, 11.) If Hi≈øtorians rightly recount, it, no fewer than ten hundred thou≈øand were de≈øtroyed: And

As to the ≈øecond, it is not nece≈ø≈øary to the making good our Ob≈øervation, that all ≈øhould be fulfilled, when it plea≈øed the Holy-Gho≈øt to make this Reflection: 'tis ≈øufficient, that it is what might very well ≈øerve to confirm the Faith of ≈øuffering Chri≈øtians at pre≈øent, (for as for the others, to who≈øe Cry the
reply is made, tis manife≈øt, they have their Reward, and are placed in a ≈øtate of Triumph, by the white Robes, which are ≈øaid to be given to every one of them, Rev. 6. 11.) that they might ≈øee that God makes Inqui≈øition for their Blood, that though there be a final day of reckoning when the Enemies of the Church ≈øhall drink of the full Cup of Vengeance, yet all is not deferred to that day; but that in the mean time, it ≈øhall be known by the Judgments that are executed on the Earth, that (as it is P≈øal. 116. 15.) precious in the ≈øight of the Lord is the death of his Saints.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the fourth Vial, Revel. 16. 8.

p.hi: AND the fourth Angel poured out his Vial upon the Sun, and power was given unto him to ≈øcorch Men with Fire.
And Men were ≈øcorcht with great Heat, and bla≈øphemed the Name of God, which hath Power over the≈øe Plagues, and they repented not to give him Glory.

div.p: By the Sun, I am apt to think can be meant nothing but Antichri≈øt in his highe≈øt Glory, ≈øuch is what he arrived at, when, as hath been ≈øhewed in the preceeding Vials, he had ≈øo far gained the A≈øcendant of tho≈øe in Soveraign Power, as to make them like the Moon and Stars, to ≈øhine only with the borrowed Light they had from him; i. e. No farther to exerci≈øe tho≈øe relieks of Soveraignty, which ≈øtill remained in them, than He thought fit to give way to it.

And if ≈øo, then the Vial poured upon the Sun, and Power thereby given him to ≈øcorch Men with Fire, will be very well interpreted by the continuance of that high U≈øurpation and Tyranny, over the ≈øecular Powers, and their Subjects, (for ≈øo Men may not unfitly be con≈øtrued;) but then the≈øe U≈øurpations and Tyranny being expre≈øt by ≈øcorching with Fire, will direct to ≈øomething that will an≈øwer that Allu≈øion: and nothing certainly
more fit to do this, than tho≈øe Excommunications, which were ≈øo frequent with them, and made u≈øe of upon every occa≈øion to ≈øupport Antichri≈øt, and his Cau≈øe: And Mens bla≈øpheming the name of God, which hath Power over the≈øe plagues, upon their being ≈øcorched with great Heat, i. e. fretted and vexed with the≈øe Darts, but withal, not repenting to give him Glory, may very aptly be explained by the great regret, and deep re≈øentments they had again≈øt the Papal Tyranny, but yet ≈øo, that whatever their prejudices again≈øt the Pope were, and his U≈øurpations, they continued ≈øtill in the profe≈ø≈øion of that corrupt Religion, he taught.

For this is, not to give Glory to God; to let the puni≈øhment lo≈øe the end for which it was ≈øent, by not being amended by it; which being the condition of tho≈øe who had the Mark of the Bea≈øt, and wor≈øhipped his Image, 'tis no wonder the Judgment is ≈øtill continued on them, and that by the means of the Bea≈øt him≈øelf; it being but righteous with God thus to avenge him≈øelf on tho≈øe who are ≈øo ≈øtupid, as not to take his former warnings.

Nor indeed could it well be otherwi≈øe, it being by ≈øuch Exorbitances, that Antichri≈øt was to ri≈øe to that heighth of Impiety, which was at la≈øt to be puni≈øhed with the final ruin of him≈øelf, and all his wicked and incorrigible Adherents.
But then a little to ≈øee, how it was this Sun under this Vial had power given him to ≈øcorch Men with Fire, and what the great Heat was, with which Men were ≈øcorched?

How Fire was brought down from Heaven by Hildebrand, or Gregory the ≈øeventh, we have above touched it, ch. 5. p. 19. With relation to the Excommunications by him thundered out again≈øt the Emperor, and ≈øhall now, for the farther explication of it only add, that there's nothing more familiar with the Popes them≈øelves, than to expre≈øs ≈øuch their Cen≈øures by Thunder and Lightning, which in the propriety of Speech is Fire from Heaven; and if we con≈øider the≈øe in the end to which they pretended to make them ≈øerve, was it not to ≈øignifie the fire of Gods Wrath, and Indignation, they hereby taking upon them≈øelves to denounce his di≈øplea≈øure towards Offenders.

'Tis true indeed, applying this to Hildebrand, there was ≈øomething in that In≈øolent U≈øurper that ≈øeemed literally to explain this; for ≈øo Cardinal Benno in his Book Entituled, Vita & ge≈øta Hildibrandi, &c. relates it, cum vellet, manicas ≈øuas di≈øcutiebat, & in modum ≈øcintillarum ignis di≈ø≈øiliebat, & eis miraculis oculos ≈øimplicium veluti ≈øigno ≈øanctitatis ludificabat; when he li≈øt he u≈øed to ≈øhake his Sleeves, and Fire did fly out in mannner of Sparks, and by tho≈øe Miracles, as by a ≈øign of Holine≈øs he deluded the Eyes of the ≈øimple.

And the Patern Hildebrand gave in his Excommunicating, as Henry, Emperor of the We≈øt, ≈øo Nicephonus, Emperor of the Ea≈øt, (for him likewi≈øe he pretended to excommunicate, Anno 1078) his Followers have not been wanting to tran≈øcribe; thus Calixtus the 2d. Anno 1119, Excommunicates the Emperor at Rhemes;
Adrian the 4th doth the ≈øame to Frederic. 1159, Innocent the 3d to Philip 1201, and to Raimond, Earl of Tholou≈øe, 1208, and again to Otho twice, viz. 1210, and 1211, and Honorius the 3d to Frederic, 1221, which Innocent the 4th renews Anno 1242, and Anno 1245, depo≈øes him, ≈øends ≈øome to kill Frederi. c. 1247; Excommunicates Conrad 1251; ≈øends Forces again≈øt Conrad, and offers Sicily to Richard Earl of Cornwal, who refu≈øeth it: Urban 4th Excommunicates Manfred 1262. Nicolas the 3d altered the form of Government in Rome, and took away the Title of Vicar of the Empire, from Chharles 1278. Martin the 4th Excommunicates and depo≈øes Peter of Arragon, and gives it to Charles Valois, younge≈øt Son to the King of France, 1283. Honorius the 5th continueth the Excommunication. All this, excepting what was done by Gregory the 7th, in the time of the Expeditions to the Holy Land: And if we look farther, (though I make it not nece≈ø≈øary, that every Vial mu≈øt ju≈øt ≈øuceed one another, but as I have before noted it, it is no incon≈øi≈øtency to ≈øuppo≈øe them to be contemporary, or in the ≈øame Age and time,) but I ≈øay if we look farther we ≈øhall ≈øee this great Heat which ≈øcorched Men, to be ≈øtill continued, if not encrea≈øed; mo≈øt frequent indeed, and almo≈øt upon every occa≈øion was this Fire Heaven, or Excommunications made u≈øe of.

Thus Anno 1297, Boniface the 8th depo≈øeth John, and Peter of Columna Cardinals, and pro≈øecuteth their Families; and that we may ≈øee what their Opinion was of the extent of their Power, at the Jubilee 1300. He ≈øtiles him≈øelf Lord in Spirituals, and Temporals,, and Anno 1301. He excommunicates the French King for burning his Bull, by which he commanded him to acknowledge him≈øelf his Va≈ø≈øal, and 1302 giveth France to the Emperor; this is that Baniface of whom it was ≈øaid (a form of Speech Baronius applies to ≈øeveral others of the Popes) qu√≤d intrarit ut Vulpes, regnaverit ut Leo, mortuus ≈øit ut Canis, That he came in as a Fox, reigned as a Lion, and died like a Dog.

Anno 1317. John the 22d boa≈øts that he had Power to depo≈øe Kings, (but was oppo≈øed herein by Ockham) and de facto, fir≈øt excommunicates Vi≈øcount Milan, and after great conte≈øts with Lewis of Bavaria, or Lewis the 4th cho≈øen Emperor, he Excommunicates him Anno 1324, and that which incen≈øed him to it, is ≈øuppo≈øed to be the offence he took at the Stile Ulric, the Emperor's Secretary (though without his knowledge) had given him in his Letters, of the Bea≈øt ri≈øing out of the Sea. And Anno 1329 the Pope publi≈øhes his Excommunication again≈øt the Emperor the ≈øecond time; which Bennet the 12th, Anno 1335 likewi≈øe continues, and makes King Edward the 3d of England, Vicar of the Empire: The ≈øaid Excommunication is al≈øo continued afterward by Clement the 6th Anno 1343, and Ab≈øolution denied to the Emperor, unle≈øs he would re≈øign the Empire to the Pope; which he refu≈øing Anno 1346. He cau≈øes ≈øome of the Electors to chu≈øe a new Emperor, and to depo≈øe Lewis, whom he had branded with the Stile of Heretic, and Schi≈ømatick.

And here I ≈øhall put a ≈øtop to what I have to ≈øay on this head, the Princes of the Empire upon the occa≈øion of the Treatment Lewis met with for ≈øo many years together from ≈øeveral of the Popes, having, as I may ≈øay, put their ≈øtop too to this Exorbitant Power, the Popes had for ≈øeveral Ages tyrannized over them with; For ≈øo it was deereed at Franckfort, Anno 1347. That the Yoak of the Pope ≈øhould be ca≈øt off, qu√≤d ≈øervus ≈øervorum fa≈øtu, libidineque dominandi, ita in≈øaniat & in preceps abeat: Becau≈øe he who was the Servant of Servants,
out of an Haughtine≈øs and Lu≈øt of Ruling, did ≈øo rage and run headlong into ≈øuch ra≈øh and precipitate things: And as for Charles the 4th. (whom the afore≈øaid Clement had cau≈øed to be cho≈øen Emperor in the place of Lewis, whom he had depo≈øed) they deny him to be lawfully cho≈øen, as being neither cho≈øen nor Crowned in the Places proper for either, as al≈øo becau≈øe it was all a clancular proceeding, and when there was no Vacancy of the Empire; whereupon they chu≈øe King Edward the third of England; but he having Affairs of his own to mind, returns his Thanks for the great honour done him, and waves it.

The Pope however ≈øends his Legate after the Death of Lewis, to ab≈øolve the Princes of the Empire, who adhered to Lewis, on condition they would ≈øwear that the Emperor had no Power to depo≈øe the Pope, and that from thenceforward they would not obey their Emperor, unle≈øs he be approved as Emperor by the Pope: The Eccle≈øia≈øticks mo≈øt readily approve this, and the Laicks as fiercely oppo≈øe it; whereupon the Pope is forced to abate ≈øomething (let me ≈øo expre≈øs it) of this great Heat, with which they had ≈øo long ≈øcorched Men, and remit this Oath, and ab≈øolve them from the Excommunication.

And this may be ≈øufficient to explain this Vial: Only here, as before, it will be asked what is this to the Fall of Antichri≈øt? The≈øe and ≈øuch like In≈øtances, (for many more might be given, and particularly in our own Story, witne≈øs (1.) the Controver≈øy between William the ≈øecond, and Urban the ≈øecond, Anno 1097. in the Ca≈øe of An≈øelm's appealing to the Pope, who was thereupon about to Excommunicate the King, but having a little before excommunicated the Emperor Henry the fourth, he forbore it, le≈øt otherwi≈øe Excommunications by being made common, might be ≈ølighted; as al≈øo (2.) between him, and Henry the fir≈øt, in the ca≈øe of Inve≈øtitutes, in which An≈øelm likewi≈øe oppo≈øed the King in behalf of the Pope's Preten≈øions to them. (3.) Between him, i. e. his Legate, and King Stephen; and again, (4.) in the ca≈øe of the Legatine Powee between him and Henry the Second. (5.) Between him, and King John, whom the Excommunicated, and Interdicted the Kingdom; and upon his ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to him, at the in≈øtance of Pandulphus, at who≈øe Feet he laid down his Crown to be di≈øpo≈øed of as the Pope ≈øhould plea≈øe, which Pandulphus took up, and kept
it three or four days; nor re≈øtoring it then, but upon condition that he and his Succe≈ø≈øors ≈øhould hold the Kingdom of the See of Rome, at the annual Tribute of 1000 Marks; which was the great occa≈øion of that Slavery in which Rome ≈øo long held this our Nation,) all tending to aggrandize him in his mo≈øt in≈øolent Tyranny; but if ≈øo yet 'tis too for the Encrea≈øe of that Guilt, which will at la≈øt be ≈øo thorowly avenged; as will appear, by that time we ≈øhall have rellected on the following Vials: The fir≈øt whereof, i. e. the fifth, is directly on Antichri≈øt, i. e. The very Seat of the Bea≈øt.

The ≈øecond or ≈øixth is likewi≈øe on Antichrist, though ≈øo as to affect the whole Seat of the Roman and Mahometan Empires, i. e. The Ea≈øtern, and We≈øtern Empires thus joined again, for they ≈øhall be both then ha≈øtening towards the day of Vengeance.

And as for the third or ≈øeventh, it is to end in the final Ruin of both, and all the Antichri≈øtian Powers under them; or rather in the Kingdom of Chri≈øt ≈øet up again≈øt Antichri≈øt in its utmo≈øt extent, in that la≈øting Triumph, he ≈øhall then give his Church over him, and all other her Enemies.

But then, as in this Vial, we have been now ≈øpeaking of, ≈øo in that which next follows, this will be again to be ob≈øerved, that it is not nece≈ø≈øary it ≈øhould immediately ≈øucceed the other; or not to be to begin, till the other is fully expired; no, it is nece≈ø≈øary in the nature of the thing, that ≈øeveral of the Vials ≈øhould be contemporary with one another, fora≈ømuch as they are Puni≈øhments for Sin, and did not the Sin continue (to which Men are often judicially given up) the Puni≈øhment inflicted for it, would not be ≈øo agreeable to the manner of Gods proceeding in the ways of his Judgment, the Rule being, I≈øaiah 27. 9. By this therefore ≈øhall the Iniquity of Jacob be purged, and this is all the fruit to take away his Sin.

Now then the≈øe being ≈øpoken of as di≈øtinct Vials, i. e. The Puni≈øhment and Sins which bring them on; if in≈øtead of having their Iniquity purged, Men ≈øhall run into more gro≈øs, and hainous Iniquity; if in≈øtead of that Fruit, they ought to bring forth upon the Cha≈øti≈øement, which is to take away their ≈øin, they ≈øhall fructifie only in Malice, and Wickedne≈øs, if, (which is the ca≈øe in the≈øe Vials) they, who are puni≈øhed for having the Mark
of the Bea≈øt on them, and wor≈øhipping his Image, ≈øhall continue ≈øtill to wear that Mark, and wor≈øhip his Image, which I take to belong to the ≈øecond, third, and fourth Vials, (for on ≈øuch it is, (not ≈øo properly on the Bea≈øt him≈øelf) they are poured out) what can be expected, but that the Plague ≈øhould go along with the Sin, that calls for it down? And that if the Bea≈øt him≈øelf do not ≈øo immediately ≈øuffer in tho≈øe Vials, that it ≈øhould be, becau≈øe to Him more particular Judgments are re≈øerved, or both He and they to go on from one wickedne≈øs to another, till there be no Remedy, 2 Chron. 36. 16.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the fifth Vial, Rev. 16. 10, 11.

p.hi: AND the fifth Angel poured out his Vial upon the ≈øeat of the Bea≈øt, and his Kingdom was full of Darkne≈øs, and they gnawed their Tongues for Pain.
And bla≈øphemed the God of Heaven, becau≈øe of their Pains, and their ≈øores, and repented not of their Deeds.

div.p: What is the ≈øeat of the Bea≈øt, but Rome? What the Vial poured out upon his ≈øeat, but the depriving it of what gives it its Lu≈øtre, Dignity, and Wealth, i. e. (as it is expre≈øt in the former Vial) of its Sun? the Pope I mean, who≈øe more benign a≈øpect and influence were ≈øo highly beneficial to it, whil≈øt it was the place of his Re≈øidence; but being removed thence, how is its Greatne≈øs and Glory forthwith Eclip≈øed? How all things black and dark, and under the thicke≈øt Cloud?

Now, when happened this, but when Clement the fifth Anno 1305, being cho≈øen Pope in his ab≈øence in France, called the Cardinals thither, and ≈øettled his Re≈øidence at Avignon? 'Twas now the City that was full of People, ≈øat ≈øolitary, and became as a Widdow; now ≈øhe that was great among the Nations, and Prince≈øs among the Provinces, became Tributary, Lam. 1. 1. She that before received the Riches of ≈øo great a part of the World,
that had ≈øo great Honour and Devotion paid to her, now ≈øends her Wealth, and pays homage her≈øelf to another ≈øhrine: This la≈øted for ≈øeventy four Years together, till Gregory the Eleventh brought back his See to Rome; but ≈øo that after his Death, the French Cardinals would have a Pope of their Nation, and accordingly cho≈øe Clement the 7th, the re≈øt of the Cardinals having cho≈øen Urban the ≈øixth: Urban keepeth at Rome, but Clement at Avignon: The Schi≈øm continued for above forty Years, for the cure whereof, a Council is called at Pi≈øa, which creates Alexander the fifth Pope; ≈øo that now there are three Popes at once, Gregory the Twelfth, (for he was cho≈øen to ≈øucceed at Rome,) Bennet the thirteenth to ≈øucceed Clement the ≈øeventh in France, and Alexander the fifth; and not long after John the 23d, and after him Martin the fifth, upon which the Schi≈øm ended.

But ≈øuch were the conte≈øts, prevarications, and cruelties of tho≈øe Times, ≈øuch the Barbarities of the≈øe Vicars of Chri≈øt, (as they would all fain be ≈øtiled) that it is a ≈øhame they ≈øhould be named among Chri≈øtians: I ≈øhall give but one or two In≈øtances.
The fir≈øt is that of Urban the 5th, wrapping up five Cardinals in Bags, and commanding them to be ca≈øt into the Sea.

The ≈øecond, that of Innocent the ≈øeventh, who, when the Romans were earne≈øt with him to take away the Schi≈øm (that had been ≈øo long in the Church), and that he would extingui≈øh the Wars and Seditions; the King of France having promi≈øed his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance herein, and Peter de Luna, the Antipope no way re≈øi≈øting ≈øuch an accord, he ≈øent the Romans (who thus addre≈øt him) to Lewis his Nephew, then re≈øiding at the Ho≈øpital of the Holy-Gho≈øt in Saxia, and by his Authority they are forthwith all Murthered, and thrown out at the Windows, and the rea≈øon given for it was, Eo modo tolli ≈øeditiones & Schi≈øma, non alio quidem po≈ø≈øe, That that was the way that Seditions and Schi≈øms were to be taken away, and that it could be done no other way. So Longus a Coriolano. p. 373, 374.

He that ≈øhall read the Hi≈øtory of tho≈øe times, ≈øhall not need to go far for an Expo≈øitor to explain to him, what is to be under≈øtood by the Beasts Kingdom being full of Darkne≈øs, and they gnawing their Tongues for pain; ≈øuch the Envy, and bitter
Malice they had again≈øt one another, ≈øuch the Torment, Vexation, and Rancour of their envenomed Minds, ≈øuch the di≈øorder and confu≈øion that was among them, every thing dark, and black as Hell it ≈øelf, from whence it came:

As neither will he for a Comment on what follows, viz. Their bla≈øphemingthe God of Heaven becau≈øe of their Pains, and their Sares, and repenting not of their Deeds: For what could be ≈øo highly to the di≈øhonour of God him≈øelf, what ≈øo much to Bla≈øpheme his Name, as to pretend Religion, the cau≈øe of Chri≈øt, and the Right of governing his Church; for all their exce≈øs and outrage? And to ≈øay no more, to u≈øe his Holy Name in thus Excommunicating one another? What ≈øo much for the Di≈øgrace of tho≈øe Princes, and others, who were ≈øo highly ≈øcandalized at ≈øuch Enormities, as to continue ≈øtill in Communion with tho≈øe who had (let me ≈øo ≈øpeak) Excommunicated all Holine≈øs and Charity, I may ≈øay, even Chri≈øt him≈øelf, and his Go≈øpel from their Church?

For was it not too in this Sea≈øon, that the Go≈øpel was made to give place to the Papal Con≈øtitutions, the Word of God made of none Effect through the Traditions of Men? Mark 7. 13. I mean in that Authority to which the Canon-Law was advanced? Which being begun by Cyratian Anno 1145, enlarged by Boniface the 8th, Anno 1298, and having the Clementines added to it by Clemeus the 5th, Anno 1308, and the Extravagancies by John the 22d, Anno 1320, became the Rule and Standard of Popery.

And what could this produce, but the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt darkne≈øs in the Kingdom of the Bea≈øt? For what mu≈øt the mi≈øt be, that is ca≈øt hereby upon the Under≈øtandings of Men, when in≈øtead of that Word which is a Lamp unto our Feet, and a Light unto our Path, P≈øalm 119. 105. Only ≈øuch a fatuus ignis, as that of fooli≈øh Man's Invention is, ≈øhall be allowed to guide us? How is this for the Blind to lead the Blind, and what's the Con≈øequence thereof, what can it end in, but in making both fall into the Pit?

Indeed this I could not here well pa≈øs by, as being at lea≈øt part of that heavy Judgment, which was then inf ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ icted on Antichri≈øt; not but that this darkne≈øs began earlier to ≈øpread it ≈øelf over the Kingdom of the Bea≈øt, than the time we mark out for
that particular Vial, ≈øaid here to be poured on his Seat, (according to what we have already taken notice of, viz. That it is not nece≈ø≈øary that each Vial in its full extent ≈øhould be ju≈øt confined to ≈øome one Period, wherein none other of the Vials were pouring out,) and will in ≈øome degree continue, as long as any thing of this Kingdom ≈øhall remain; for indeed the Kingdom of the Bea≈øt is nothing el≈øe but the Kingdom of Darkne≈øs, it being only by Error, and Ignorance he can hope to prevail: For let but the light of the Go≈øpel once clearly ≈øhine forth, and all Mi≈øts, and Clouds will vani≈øh forthwith, and this Kingdom of the Bea≈øt it is by that at la≈øtit is to be overthrown) will vani≈øh with them.

But one thing more is to ob≈øerved of this Vial, as it was poured out upon the Seat of the Bea≈øt; and that was, as now Princes began to de≈øpi≈øe the Power of the Popes, and make them≈øelves their Judges; it was what they had ≈øometimes attempted before, but the Popes ≈øtill got the better of them in the conte≈øt; but now they effectually made them to be depo≈øed, and ≈øubmitted them to the Authority of Councils, as in that of Con≈øtance: Nay, they came to that Indiffereucy, that ≈øeveral of them owned neither the Pope at Rome, nor at Avignon; and Charles the 6th King of France went ≈øo far, as by a publick Edict to decree, ne quis ≈øuorum Romanum, aut Avenionem excutreret ad Pontifiem, That none of his Subjects ≈øhould go either to Rome or Avignon to the Pope.

Be≈øides, it was what did not a little encrea≈øe their pains, and ≈øores, what happened to the Seat of the Bea≈øt under this Vial, from Wiclef, and his Followers, who ≈øo highly declaimed again≈øt the Pope, as being Antichri≈øt, and ≈øo ≈øtronuou≈øly oppo≈øed the Doctrines of Purgatory, of Images, of Invocation of Saints, of Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, of Indulgences, &c. For however Wiclef's Doctrine was condemned at Con≈øtance, Jerome of Prague, and John Hus Burnt for defending it, yet how did the Light of the Go≈øpel by them Preached, begin to di≈øpel the Mi≈øts and Clouds which this Kingdom of Darkne≈øs had ca≈øt abroad? How did it but make way for that clearer Light, which ≈øhone forth yet clearer at the Reformation? When according to Hus's Prophecy, (viz. Nunc quidem torretis An≈øerem, at veniet Cycnus, quem non poteritis torrere, po≈øt centum Annos Deo, & mihi re≈øpondebitis:
Now indeed you ro≈øt a Goo≈øe (alluding to his own Name, which ≈øignifies a Goo≈øe) but there will come a Swan, whom you ≈øhall not be able to ro≈øt, after 100 Years you ≈øhall an≈øwer to God and me) Luther appeared again≈øt the Corruptions of the Church of Rome.

And here let us leave them full of Darkne≈øs as they are, and gnawing their Tongues for pain, for grief and Vexation, that all they can ≈øay in the defence of their Super≈øtition and Idolatry, will never be able to ≈øilence Truth: Let them do all they can to hold the World in Darkne≈øs ≈øtill, by the denying them the u≈øe of Scripture, but the Day is dawned, and the Light is broken forth, and will dazzle the Eyes of tho≈øe Bats and Owls, who ≈øo much fly from it. The Knowledge of God's Word, (ble≈ø≈øed be his holy Name for it) will not ≈øuffer Men to be ≈øo Blind as to be led any longer by ≈øuch dark Guides: let them (≈øeeing it is their black doom ≈øo to do) Bla≈øpheme the God of Heaven; let them continue in their Impenitency, and not repent of their Deeds; but that God, whom they Bla≈øpheme is able to recover his own Glory, and will give them but too too long a day to repent, when they who have ≈øo much laboured to ≈øupport their Kingdom by it, ≈øhall them≈øelves be re≈øerved in Everla≈øting Chains of Darkne≈øs.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the ≈øixth Vial, Rev. 16. 12, 13, 14, 15, 16.
div.p: AND the ≈øixth Angel poured out his Vial upon the great River Euphrates, and the Water thereof was dried up, that the way of the Kings of the Ea≈øt might be prepared.

p.hi: And I ≈øaw three unclean Spirits like Frogs come out of the Mouth of the Dragon, and out of the Mouth of the Bea≈øt, and out of the Mouth of the fal≈øe Prophet.
For they are the Spirits of Devils, working Miracles, which go forth unto the Kings of the Earth, and of the whole World, to
gather them to the Battle of that great Day of God Almighty.
Behold I come as a Thief, ble≈ø≈øed is he that watcheth, and keepeth his Garments, le≈øt he walk naked, and they ≈øee his Shame.

div.p: And he gathered them together into a place called in the Hebrew Tongue, Amageddon.

This Vial contains a great variety of matter, and Subjects, to whom it relates, and ≈øeems to point at Events, which concern not only the fall of Antichri≈øt, under the re≈øtriction we have hitherto been ≈øpeaking of him, but of all others, (though not ≈øo preci≈øely under that Denomination) who with him ri≈øe up again≈øt the Lord and his Anointed, P≈øal. 2. 2.

And 'tis but nece≈ø≈øary we ≈øhould have this notion of it, the bu≈øine≈øs of this Vial being to u≈øher in the Kingdom of Chri≈øt on Earth, i. e. To open a way for the Return of the Jews, and the fulne≈øs of the Gentiles, which is what that Kingdom will con≈øi≈øt in; And if ≈øo, it cannot be imagined, how there ≈øhould be any left to oppo≈øe the Purity of the Chri≈øtian Religion, (which will be the great Glory of our Lords Reign,) any of his Enemies remain, who ≈øhall not be de≈øtroyed.

That indeed his Enemies ≈øhall be willing to make a pu≈øh for it, to make their la≈øt attempt again≈øt his Power, is ≈øcarce to be doubted; for if (as it is in the former Vial) they repent not after all his Plagues of their Deeds, what can be expected, but that their Impenitency will hide the things that belong to their Peace from their Eyes, and they will u≈øe all endeavours to a≈ø≈øert their unrighteous Cau≈øe?

What can be expected, but that they will band and league together to oppo≈øe their common Enemy? or if they band not, if they enter not into common Leagues and Alliances to this purpo≈øe; if they continue ≈øtill at a di≈øtance, and Enemies to one another, yet that they will all con≈øpire in the ≈øame Malice again≈øt Chri≈øt; i. e. That the Dragon, the Beast, and fal≈øe Prophet will all unite in the common cau≈øe of Hell, and gather them≈øelves together to the Battle of that great day of God Almighty? Such is the precipitate Malice, ≈øuch the blind Envy, ≈øuch the unaccountable De≈øpair of the Devil, and his wicked In≈øtruments, that though they are certain, nothing but ruin can be the Con≈øequence, they cannot deny them≈øelves the ≈øatisfaction of the attempt: Lucifer, under whom they have li≈øted, will
a≈øcend, and be like the mo≈øt high; will in his boundle≈øs Pride and Ambition be a≈øpiring to ≈øet him≈øelf above God, although he thereby be but preparing his own Hell, and fitting him≈øelf for everlu≈øting Chains of Darkne≈øs.

But then Chains and Darkne≈øs will be their Lot, Ruin and De≈øtruction will attend all their Enterpri≈øes, and that in the Extent, Manner, and Circum≈øtances of it, is what is here more particularly to be con≈øidered.
Now that I ≈øhall do in the Method the Vial is delivered.
1. I ≈øhall con≈øider what is to be under≈øtood by the great River Euphrates, and the water thereof, and how that is to be dried up?
2. What by the way of the Kings of the Ea≈øt to be prepared, and how the drying up of the Water of the great River Euphrates will prepare their way?
3. What is to be meant by the three unclean Spirits like Frogs, coming out of the Mouth of the Dragon, and out of the Mouth of the Bea≈øt, and out of the Mouth of the fal≈øe Prophet?
4. Why Chri≈øt is ≈øaid to come as a Thief at this time, and to declare tho≈øe Ble≈ø≈øed that ≈øhall then Watch?
5. The turn he ≈øhall give to Affairs, in gathering them into a place, called in the Hebrew Tongue, Amageddon?
1. What is to be under≈øtood by the great River Euphrates, and the Water thereof, and how that is to be dried up?

Euphrates may be taken either literally, or in a figurative ≈øen≈øe; either for the River it ≈øelf, and its Waters, in the common Notion we have of the≈øe, or for tho≈øe who are Borderers on it; and it is the ≈øtile the Holy Gho≈øt makes u≈øe of, Rev. 17. 15. to expre≈øs Peoples, Multitudes, Nations, and Tongues, by Waters.

If in the fir≈øt ≈øen≈øe we take this, viz. For the River it ≈øelf, and its Waters, in the common notion we have of the≈øe; then the drying up the Water thereof under this Vial, will be either like what happened in the drying up the Red-Sea for the Children of I≈ørael to pa≈øs through it towards Canaan, or what hath already happened to Euphrates it ≈øelf at the taking of Babylon by Cyrus, who made wide and deep Trenches, whereby to divert it Streams, and ≈øo came upon that City unawares in the night of their ≈øolemn Fea≈øt; the ≈øame Stratagem by
which Semiramis and Alexander are likewi≈øe reported to have taken it, as Frontinus relates, l. 3. c. 7. i. e. This will be, Either

By Miracle; God immediately interpo≈øing as he then did, for the deliverance of his People, the ≈øame People of I≈ørael, as we ≈øhall afterwards ≈øhew, for whom he wrought the former Miracle, and in order to his bringing them into the ≈øame Canaan, or Land of Promi≈øe; Or
By ≈øome artificial Stratagem, whereby they ≈øhall be enabled to open to them≈øelves a pa≈ø≈øage thorow it.
But if in the latter Sen≈øe, Euphrates, and its Waters are to be taken, viz. for tho≈øe who are Borderers on, or Inhabitants near or about it; Then

The drying up the Water thereof, will be, cau≈øing the People who thus inhabit, or border on or about it, like the Sea opening on this, or on that ≈øide, no longer to hinder the pa≈ø≈øage of the ten Tribes (for it is in all likelihood there the ten Tribes, at lea≈øt, great part of them are; nay, whether not mixt among the Turks them≈øelves is very doubtful) into Canaan, and returning to Jeru≈øalem, whether in all probability they ≈øhall be then gathered. And this makes way for our ≈øecond Enquiry, viz.
2. What is to be under≈øtood by the way that is to be prepared for the Kings of the Ea≈øt, and how the drying up of the Water of the great River Euphrates will prepare their way?

The preparing the way for the Kings of the Ea≈øt, i. e. For tho≈øe va≈øt Dominions and Countries that lye Ea≈øtward, (for Kings come not without their People, and Subjects to attend them) will ≈øignifie that great Acce≈ø≈øion ≈øhall in tho≈øe parts of the World be there made to the Go≈øpel, by a way being opened for them to embrace it; or if by the Kings of the East we under≈øtand tho≈øe, who de jure, or of right are ≈øuch, viz. The Seed of Abraham, or the Jews, who≈øe the Promi≈øes are, then will this import (as is already ≈øaid) a way being made for them through Euphrates, in the twofold Sen≈øe we have given of it; to return into their own Country, and be there po≈ø≈øe≈øt of that Soveraignty over other Nations, that belongs to them; and being there, without confining their Return to
tho≈øe who ≈øhall come Ea≈øtward of Euphrates (for from all parts of the World ≈øhall they at lea≈øt ≈øome of them be gathered to Jeru≈øalem, as is otherwhere Prophe≈øied; I≈øaiah 11. 11, 12, 14, 15, 16. Ezek. 37. 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28.) They may be called the Kings of the Ea≈øt particularly (for ≈øo Jeru≈øalem, and Canaan are called the Ea≈øt,) becau≈øe there is to be the chief Seat of the Empire, there they to be again E≈øtabli≈øhed.

And it is more than probable it ≈øhould be ≈øo, if we con≈øider the many Prophe≈øies which expre≈øly foretel it, and have never yet been fulfilled to them. 'Tis impo≈ø≈øible that there ≈øhould not be glorious times behind for the Seed of Abraham, and as impo≈ø≈øible that the Kings of Ea≈øt, (the Nations among≈øt which they are ≈øcattered, tho≈øe va≈øt Dominions and Countries which lye Ea≈øtward, and have hitherto been ≈øo much in the dark, as to the knowledge of the Go≈øpel) ≈øhould not ≈øhare in that Glory with them.

And, methinks I cannot but upon this occa≈øion apply what we read, Ieremiah 50. 38. A drought is upon her Waters, and they ≈øhall be dried up; and again, chap. 51. 32. The Pa≈ø≈øages are ≈øtopt; it is with reference to Euphrates, and the drying up of its Water, the Prophet there ≈øpeaks, when Babylon was to be taken by Cyrus, as we have already ≈øhewed, it really happened; but it we con≈øider the whole context, and the gracious expre≈ø≈øions of God to his People, beyond what hath ever yet been verified to them; ≈øuch as what occurs, ch. 51. 5. For I≈ørael hath not been for≈øaken, nor Judah of his God, of the Lord of Hosts: And ver. 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24. The Portion of Iacob is not like them, for he is the former of all things, and I≈ørael is the Rod of his Inheritance, the Lord of Ho≈øts his Name.

Who Antichri≈øt is. Antichri≈øt is the fal≈øhood of Eternal Damnation, covered with the appearance of Truth, and of the Righteou≈øne≈øs of Chri≈øt and his Spou≈øe: Oppo≈øed in like manner to the way of Truth, of Ju≈øtice, of Faith, of Hope, of Charity, and to a moral Life, and the mini≈øterial truth of the Church; 'tis menaged by fal≈øe Apo≈øtles, and mo≈øt ob≈øtinately maintained on all hands. His Mini≈øters are called Fal≈øe Prophets, Lyars, Mini≈øters of Darkne≈øs, the Spirit of Error, the Where in the Revelation, the Mother of Fornication, Clouds without Water, Autumnal Trees dead, and twice pulled up by the Root, Waters of the cruel Sea, Wandring Stars, Balaamites, and Egyptians.

by Chri≈øt, and truly admini≈øtred in the Church of Chri≈øt; which as the Faithful partake of by Faith, Hope, and Charity, ≈øo he oppo≈øes it by worldly Wi≈ødom, by fal≈øe Religion, by feigned Goodne≈øs, by Spiritual Power, by ≈øecular Tyranny, by Riches, Honours, and Dignities, by Luxury, and the Delights of the World.

And this Iniquity of Antichri≈øt is directly again≈øt the fir≈øt Article of Faith, and again≈øt the fir≈øt Commandment of the Law.

The ≈øecond cau≈øe. In like manner an Inordinate love of the World, which is in Antichri≈øt, and that is it from whence ≈øprung all the evils, and ≈øins that are in the Church, in tho≈øe who are the Guides to govern her, and her Officers, who ≈øin without any re≈øtraint; the≈øe are again≈øt the Truth of the Faith, and again≈øt the knowledge of God the Father, as St. John Witne≈ø≈øes, He that ≈øins, neither knows, nor hath ≈øeen God, for if any one love the World, the love of the Father is not in him.

The ≈øecond Iniquity of Antichri≈øt is tru≈øting in the Creatures. The ≈øecond Iniquity of Antichri≈øt lies in the hope, which he gives of Pardon, of Grace, of Righteou≈øne≈øs, of Truth, and of Life Eternal, as being what are not in Chri≈øt, nor in God by Chri≈øt, but in men living, or dead, in Authorities, in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Ceremonies, in Benedictions, in Sacrifices, in Prayers, and in the other things above mention'd, and not in true Faith, which produces repentance by Charity, and makes men to depart from evil, and brings them to do good. So that Antichri≈øt teaches not firmly to tru≈øt on ≈øuch things, as
Regeneration, Spiritual Confirmation, or Communion, Remi≈ø≈øion of Sins, and everla≈øting Sanctification, but to tru≈øt in the Sacraments, or in his ba≈øe Simony, by which the people is deluded, ≈øo that ≈øelling all things, he hath invented many Ordinances, old and new, to get Money, ≈øuffering, if any one hath done this or that, hereby to obtain Grace and Life. And this double Iniquity, is properly called in the Scriptures, Adultery, or Whoredom,; and therefore tho≈øe Mini≈øters, who lead the brutal People in the≈øe Errors, are called the Whore in the Revelation. And this Iniquity is again≈øt the ≈øecond Article, and al≈øo again≈øt the ≈øecond and third Commandment of the Law.

The third Iniquity of Antichri≈øt is the E≈øtabli≈øhing the merit of Works. The third Iniquity of Antichrist lies in this, That he hath invented, be≈øides what hath been already ≈øaid, fal≈øe Religions, and Rules, and Mona≈øteries, giving hopes of obtaining Grace by building of certain Churches. As al≈øo in this, viz. If any one often, and devoutly hears Ma≈øs, if he hath partaken of the Sacraments, if he hath been at Confe≈ø≈øion (things that rarely ≈øhew men to be contrite) or if they have ≈øatisfied by Fa≈øtings, and emptying the Pur≈øe, or if they have been, or are Members of the Romi≈øh Church. Or whether they have not devoted them≈øelves already, or vowed to be of any Order, either to take the Cap, or Monks Hood, which they affirm again≈øt all Truth, that they are obliged to. And this Iniquity of Antichri≈øt is directly again≈øt the 8th Article of the Creed, I believe in the Holy Ghost.

The fourth Iniquity of Antichri≈øt is covering all with ≈øpecious titles. The fourth Iniquity of Antichri≈øt lies in this, That as he is the fourth Bea≈øt before de≈øcribed by Daniel, and the Apocalyptick Whore, he covers him≈øelf neverthele≈øs with the Authority, Power, Dignity of Mini≈øters, Officers, and Scriptures; and equals, and compares him≈øelf to the true, and holy Mother Church, wherein Salvation Mini≈øterially is, and no where el≈øe; wherein is Truth of Life, and of Doctrine, and of the Sacraments: For if he ≈øhould not cover both him≈øelf, and his wicked Mini≈øters, the≈øe being known to be open ≈øinners, he would be abandon'd by all. For Emperors, and Kings, and Princes, looking upon him to be the true, and holy Mother Church, have loved, and endowed him contrary to the Commandment of God. And this Iniquity of Mini≈øters, and tho≈øe
≈øubject to him, who are thus upheld in error and ≈øin, is directly again≈øt the 9th Article, I believe the Holy Church. This as to what re≈øpects the fir≈øt part.

Of Unction and the Super≈øtitious Shaving of Prie≈øts and Monks. Secondly, for as much as they who partake only of the outward Ceremonies, ordain'd by humane Inventions, believe, and hope to partake of the Truth of the Pa≈øtoral Offices and Cures, provided that they be ≈øhorn like Lambs, and Anointed, and ble≈ø≈øed by touching the Book, and Calice with the hand, they profe≈øs to be ordain'd, as Prie≈øts ought. In like manner (as is above ≈øaid) the people, who are under them, communicating by the words, ≈øigns, and outward Exerci≈øes, and their diver≈øe Actions, think they partake of the Truth drawn out from them. And this is again≈øt another part of the 9th Article, I believe the Communion of Saints. Wherefore it's nece≈ø≈øary to depart from the wicked Communion of Monks, by whom Carnal men are drawn in, they through their Avarice making them tru≈øt in ≈øuch vain things, ≈øo that though they be Luxurious, or Covetous, yet if they do but give to them, they promi≈øe them that they ≈øhall partake of their Poverty and Cha≈øtity.

The fifth Iniquity of Antichri≈øt, is their pre≈øumption to Pardon ≈øin. The fifth Iniquity of Antichri≈øt lies in this, That they feign, and promi≈øe Pardon, and Remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øins to Sinners, who are not truly contrite, and cea≈øe not to continue in their wicked doings; and in the fir≈øt place, through Avarice, they promi≈øe them Remi≈ø≈øion of their ≈øins, upon Auricular Confe≈ø≈øion, and the Ab≈øolution of Man for their Pilgrimages: And this Iniquity is again≈øt the 11th Article of the Faith, I believe the forgivene≈øs of ≈øins. For that is Authoritatively in God, and Mini≈øterially in Chri≈øt, by Faith, Hope, Repentance, Charity, Obedience of the Word, and in man by participation.

The ≈øixth Iniquity is, to deceive by Purgatory. The ≈øixth Iniquity con≈øi≈øts in this, That they ≈øerve them≈øelves, and hope to the end of their life, in the fore-mention'd cover'd Iniquities, and ≈øpecially in Extreme Unction, and the dream of Purgatory, ≈øo that the ignorant, and more rude per≈øervere in their Error, they giving them to under≈øtand, that they are ab≈øolved from their ≈øins, though they never for≈øake them with a good will, and to hope for remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øins, and life eternal. And this Iniquity is directly again≈øt the eleventh and twelfth Article of the Faith.
